sources.chunk_preview: HD MWF schedule via Permacath, not declared ESRD at this time; More alert; follows commands with Right side; Increased movement to command on left side; Trach placed 3/10 (25 days old), Tolerating con
sources.chunk_full:
HD MWF schedule via Permacath, not declared ESRD at this time; More alert; follows commands with Right side; Increased movement to command on left side; Trach placed 3/10 (25 days old), Tolerating continuous 35 % Trach Collar, ventilator out of room; Thoracentesis 3/30 with 1.5L removed; PEG/TF; ST to trial speaking valve as tolerated; PT/OT following with Max assistance; ST evals needed for speaking valve trials when appropriate.
CM follow up with wife, no additional information regarding patient current insurance providers offering any rehab benefits.
Now, since patient is off ventilator; SNF is more appropriate level of care; Multiple referrals in progress in the Ft Pierce area; Notes attached to referrals regarding if any SNF able to accept patient with Florida Medicaid pending status.
Wife provided with list of referrals for review
CM follow up with Parallon regarding status of Florida Medicaid application status -- filed 3/13 and updated information sent 3/20
Barrier: Heparin gtt, New IHD MWF schedule; Florida Medicaid Pending
4/3/2023 05:56 PM by Kimberly Kilgore ---
Patient discussed in MDR; Continue with Trach/Vent with TCT as tolerated; PEG/TF; IHD continues MWF schedule, Nephrology following AKI, monitoring for renal recovery; Plan for possible renal bx; Awake, alert; Left Hemiparesis -- attemptng to follow commands weakly on left; Follows commands Rt side; Heparin Gtt; Awaiting new helmet for better fit; PT/OT following with updtaed evaluations pending.
Patient Freedom Life Insurance only covers $200 toward LTACH; No coverage for SNF; IPT. HHC
Printed on 4/16/24 1027
Page 610
MEMORIAL UNIV MED CTR 0607
MEMORIAL HEALTH 4700 WATERS AVE SAVANNAH GA 31404-6220
Ward, Frank MRN: 40162221, DOB: 11/12/1969, Sex: M Adm: 2/17/2023, D/C: 5/3/2023
02/17/2023 - ED to Hosp-Admission (Discharged) in SAV 2 HV NEURO ICU (continued)
Clinical Notes (group 1 of 20) (continued)
Patient not eligible for Workman Comp due to he was an independent contractor Additional Occupation and Hazzard Insurance policy declined coverage due to Stroke diagnosis was not work related injury and deemed normal life event
3/31/2023 04:35 PM by Kimberly Kilgore -
CM received call back from Kindred in Melbourne Florida LTACH; States patient Freedom Life UHC plan only pays $200 day for LTACH and does not have coverage for HHC, SNF or Rehab. Kindred LTACH has declined acceptance due to insufficient insurance coverage for LTACH
Patient wife updated with above information; states she is going to call patient insurance provider to see what else can be done regarding patient insurance for post acute care. Will inquire whether she can change to another insurance plan that will provide coverage for post acute care.
3/31/2023 11:53 AM by Kimberly Kilgore -
CM follow up with Kindred LTACH in Melborne Florida; Able to be connected with Director of Admissions, Mary Jo Hilb (561-234-5993); Discussed LTACH referral in CarePort and available for review and CM has had no success in contacting admissions department in spite of multiple messages left; Mary Jo states they do not have onsite admissions at facility and states fax number in Careport is incorrect; Mary Jo requests clinical information/referral be faxed to (321-733-5 799) ; Referral re-faxed as requested; Mary Jo state she will contact Nort Fla/Ga liaison to contact CM for update on patient status
Addendum: CM received call from Kindred liaison, Amy Brannon ( 904-907-3162) , updated on status of patient, Amy able to log into Careport and see Clinical information; Requests recent MAR be added. States will need to verify insurance information with his Freedom Life Plan in regards to LTACH coverage. CM also provided contact number for wife.

FRANK WARD, JR. AND RACHAEL WARD PLAINTIFF(S),
VS.
SAVANNAH HEALTH SERVICES, LLC D/B/A MEMORIAL HEALTH UNIVERSITY MEDICAL CENTER; SOUND INPATIENT PHYSICIANS, INC; EVERETTE THOMBS, JR., MD; THE NEUROLOGICAL INSTITUTE OF SAVANNAH & CENTER FOR SPINE, PC; CHRISTINE LOCKEY, NP; AYA HEALTHCARE LOCAL, LLC; AYA HEALTHCARE SERVICES, INC .; JANE DOES 1-5 AND XYZ CORP 1-5 DEFENDANT(S).
CASE NO .: STCV24-03188
DEFENDANTS REQUEST FOR THE PRODUCTION OF DOCUMENTS TO A NON-
PARTY
To: Brooks Rehabilitation Hospital 3599 University Blvd S. Jacksonville, FL, 32216
Attn: Billing Records Custodian
Re:
NAME : Frank Ward
DOB: 11/12/1969 SSN: 3738
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 9-11-34(c)(2) as well as for use pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(6), O.C.G.A. § 24-9-902(11)(12) and O.C.G.A. § 24-8-826, you are hereby requested to produce the following documents for inspection and copying at the offices of Ontellus, 910 Louisiana St., Suite 4500, Houston, Texas 77002 within thirty (30) days after service of this Request.
In lieu of personal production, photocopies of the documents may be mailed to the above- referenced address on or before thirty (30) days from receipt.
As used herein, the term "document" shall mean the original of every writing or record of every type and description that is in your actual and/or constructive possession, custody or control. The material shall include without limitation, correspondence, memorandum, stenographic and handwritten notes, studies, publications, books, pamphlets, voice recording, reports, minutes, telegrams, telexes, memoranda of agreement, diaries, calendars, invoices, bills, summaries, checks, wage histories, employment contracts, personnel file and medical records. The request includes every copy of such
Order No .: 671839.006
671839.006 - Brooks Rehabilitation Hospital
document whether or not the original is in your possession, custody or control. Any document bearing on any side thereof any marks, such as (but not limited to) initials, stamped indicia, comments or notations, of any character, and not a part of the original text or photographic reproduction thereof, is to be considered and produced as a separate document.
Please do not produce the records prior to twenty (20) days from the date of mailing of the request in order to afford any party the opportunity to object to this request if desired. If no objection is filed within that period of time, the above-referenced statute directs you to promptly comply with this request.
The documents to be produced are as follows:
Complete billing records from first point of contact to present, including but not limited to any records/documents that may be stored digitally and/or electronically: charges, statements, explanation of benefits, payments, adjustments, write-offs, lien agreements, Letters of Protection between the facility and patient's attorney, balances paid, balances due, CPT/diagnostic codes, and itemized billing charges pertaining to any and all care, treatment, and/or examinations. All billing emails between physicians and the patient, including secure messages.
Dated:
March 25, 2025
Respectfully submitted: /s/ Kristen Cesaria
Kristen Cesario State Bar No .

إذا كان لديك أو إدى شخص صاعدة أوظة حول SilverSummit Healthplan، لديك الحق ذي الحصول على الحسن اعدة والمقومات الضرورية بداخلك من دن و أية تكلفة. للأحدث عم مترجم الصرف بـ 2880-366-844-1 .(TTY/TDD 1-844-804-6086)
Русский язык (Russian):
В случае возникновения у вас или у лица, которому вы помогаете, каких-либо вопросов о программе страхования SilverSummit Healthplan вы имеете право получить бесплатную помощь и информацию на своем родном языке. Чтобы поговорить с переводчиком, позвоните по телефону 1-844-366-2880 (TTY/TDD 1-844-804-6086).
Français (French):
Si vous-même ou une personne que vous aidez avez des questions a propos SilverSummit Healthplan, vous avez le droit de bénéficier gratuitement d'aide et d'informations dans votre langue. Pour parler à un interprète, appelez le 1-844-366-2880 (TTY/TDD 1-844-804-6086).
دارسي ( Farsi):
اثر ماء ها فسي كه به أو كمك مي كنيد مؤ البي در مورد SilverSummit Healthplan داريد، از ابن حق برغورداريد كه فمك وطالعات را -صورت رايكان به زبان خود دروانت فريد- براي صحبت كردن باجترجم ١ - تجاره (6086-804-844-1 TTY/TDD) 1-844-366-2880 تماس كهرود.
Gagana Samoa (Samoan):
'Afai e iai ni au fesili, po'o ni fesili fo'i a se isi 'o 'e fesoasoani i ai, e uiga i le FuafuagaMaloloina a le SilverSummit, e iai lau aia e sa'ili ai ni fa'amatalaga i lau lava gagana e aunoa ma se totogi. 'A 'e fia talanoa i se fa'amatala'upu, telefoni le 1-844-366-2880 (TTY/TDD 1-844-804-6086).

Falls Sie oder jemand, dem Sie helfen, Fragen zu SilverSummit Healthplan hat, haben Sie das Recht, kostenlose Hilfe und Informationen in Ihrer Sprache zu erhalten. Um mit einem Dolmetscher zu sprechen, rufen Sie bitte die Nummer 1-844-366-2880 (TTY/TDD 1-844-804-6086) an.

17. Consent to Email, Telephone Calls or Text Message for Healthcare Information, Discharge Instructions and Other Communications. If at any time I provide an email address or telephone number (whether wireless or a landline) to a Provider or EBO Servicer, I consent to receive messages from Providers and EBO Servicers regarding discharge instructions and other healthcare communications (including without limitation information about programs or services that might be of interest to me) at the email or telephone number (whether wireless or landline) that I have provided or you or your EBO Servicer have obtained or, at any text number forwarded or transferred from that number. These discharge instructions may include, but not be limited to: post-operative instructions, physician follow-up instructions, dietary information, and prescription information. The other healthcare communications may include, but are not limited to communications to family or designated representatives regarding my treatment or condition, or reminder messages to me regarding appointments formedical care, information about insurance coverage/eligibility, referrals, available treatment options and capabilities, health insurance plans, patient surveys and programs and services that might be of interest to me. I understand that providing my consent to receive such communications is not a condition of receiving services or care from Providers.
18. Use and Disclosure of Information. I consent to Providers using and disclosing healthcare information about me for purposes of treatment, payment and healthcare operations. I also consent to my health information being used and disclosed for public health and other purposes permitted by applicable law. Information covered by this consent includes, without limitation, history and physical records, emergency records, laboratory reports, operative reports, physician progress notes, nurse notes, consultations, psychological and/or psychiatric reports, drug and alcohol treatment records and discharge summaries. This consent specifically applies to genetic information and information concerning psychological conditions, psychiatric conditions, intellectual disability conditions, substance abuse disorder and chemical dependency conditions and/or infectious diseases including, but not limited to, blood borne diseases, such as HIV and AIDS.

COMPLAINT FOR DAMAGES
COME NOW Frank Ward, Jr. and Rachael Ward ("Plaintiffs") and bring this Complaint for Damages by showing the Court and Jury as follows:
Introduction
1.
Plaintiff Frank Ward suffered a stroke. The neurological team at Savannah Memorial Hospital performed a thrombectomy, and Mr. Ward was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU). Mr. Ward's condition stabilized and his motor, cognitive and verbal function improved. Mr. Ward was discharged from the ICU to the main floor of the Hospital, where he was supposed to be
1
)
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
- Clerk of Court
7
3
frequently monitored for signs of neurological decline and treated appropriately. One of the known risk factors following a stroke like Mr. Ward had is swelling of the brain which will result in further brain damage if not recognized and promptly treated. While on the Hospital floor, Mr. Ward declined in verbal, cognitive and motor function which multiple providers noted, but failed to take appropriate action. After Mr. Ward started to decline, he had an MRI of his brain. The MRI showed a recent and evolving brain bleed which would explain Mr. Ward's decline and required immediate attention. Still, the Hospital did nothing. More than 30 hours after Mr. Ward's MRI exam, he had a CT Scan of his head, confirming a brain bleed and compression of his brainstem as a result of brain swelling. As a result of Defendants' delays, Mr. Ward suffered severe brain damage. Mr. Ward now requires around-the-clock care as a result of Defendants' lack of proper care.
Parties, Jurisdiction and Venue
2.
Plaintiffs Frank Ward and Rachael Ward reside in Sparks, Nevada. Plaintiffs subject themselves to the jurisdiction and venue of this Court.

sources.chunk_preview: l expenses, has lost and continues to lose wages, has suffered and continues to suffer pain, mental anguish, fear, shock and horror of his condition, loss of use of his body, loss of enjoyment of life
sources.chunk_full:
l expenses, has lost and continues to lose wages, has suffered and continues to suffer pain, mental anguish, fear, shock and horror of his condition, loss of use of his body, loss of enjoyment of life, severe impairment of health and vigor physically and mentally, permanent disfigurement, loss of capacity to labor, physical confinement, and other harms and losses entitling Plaintiff Mr. Ward to compensation in an amount to be determined by the enlightened consciousness of a jury.
80.
As a result of her husband's stroke, Plaintiff Mrs. Ward has lost the society, companionship and services of her husband such that she too is entitled to compensation for loss of consortium in an amount to be determined by the enlightened consciousness of a jury.
81.
Defendants, in failing to get Plaintiff Mr. Ward immediate medical attention upon the presentation of worsening stroke symptoms, behaved willfully, wantonly and demonstrated behavior manifesting a conscious indifference to the consequences of their actions such that punitive damages are warranted under O.C.G.A. § 51-12-5.1.
82.
In full compliance with O.C.G.A. § 9-11-9.1 and in support of all claims for professional negligence against Defendants Nurse Roy, Nurse Robinson, and Dr. Thombs, Plaintiffs attach and incorporate herein by reference Exhibit "A", the expert Affidavit of Robert Holloway, M.D., which specifies at least one act of negligence against Defendants Nurse Roy, Nurse Robinson, Nurse Tinker, and Dr. Thombs.
19
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
wind - Clerk of Court
83.
In full compliance with O.C.G.A. § 9-11-9.1 and in support of all claims for professional negligence against Defendant NP Lokey, Plaintiffs attach and incorporate herein by reference Exhibit "B", the expert Affidavit of Yince Loh, M.D., which specifies at least one act of negligence against Defendant NP Lokey.
WHEREFORE, Plaintiffs pray for the following relief:
a) that Defendants be served with process;
b) that Plaintiffs recover from all Defendants, or from a combination of one or more of the Defendants, an amount in excess of $10,000.00 for their injuries;
c) that Plaintiffs recover money damages to compensate them for the full amount of harms and losses they have suffered due to Defendants' negligence;
d) that Plaintiff recover attorneys' fees for Defendants' bad faith and stubborn litigiousness under O.C.G.A. § 13-6-11;
e) that Plaintiff recover punitive damages pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 51-12-5.1;
f) that Plaintiffs have a trial by jury on all issues;
g) that all costs be taxed against the Defendants; and
h) for such other and further relief as the Court deems just and appropriate.
This 20th day of December, 2024.

CIVIL ACTION FILE NO. STCV24-03188
JURY TRIAL DEMANDED
COMPLAINT FOR DAMAGES
COME NOW Frank Ward, Jr. and Rachael Ward ("Plaintiffs") and bring this Complaint for Damages by showing the Court and Jury as follows:
Introduction
1.
Plaintiff Frank Ward suffered a stroke. The neurological team at Savannah Memorial Hospital performed a thrombectomy, and Mr. Ward was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU). Mr. Ward's condition stabilized and his motor, cognitive and verbal function improved. Mr. Ward was discharged from the ICU to the main floor of the Hospital, where he was supposed to be
1
)
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
- Clerk of Court
7
3
frequently monitored for signs of neurological decline and treated appropriately. One of the known risk factors following a stroke like Mr. Ward had is swelling of the brain which will result in further brain damage if not recognized and promptly treated. While on the Hospital floor, Mr. Ward declined in verbal, cognitive and motor function which multiple providers noted, but failed to take appropriate action. After Mr. Ward started to decline, he had an MRI of his brain. The MRI showed a recent and evolving brain bleed which would explain Mr. Ward's decline and required immediate attention. Still, the Hospital did nothing. More than 30 hours after Mr. Ward's MRI exam, he had a CT Scan of his head, confirming a brain bleed and compression of his brainstem as a result of brain swelling. As a result of Defendants' delays, Mr. Ward suffered severe brain damage. Mr. Ward now requires around-the-clock care as a result of Defendants' lack of proper care.
Parties, Jurisdiction and Venue
2.
Plaintiffs Frank Ward and Rachael Ward reside in Sparks, Nevada. Plaintiffs subject themselves to the jurisdiction and venue of this Court.
3.

Personally appeared before me, the undersigned officer, duly authorized to administer oaths, , an authorized representative of Brooks Rehabilitation Hospital who, upon duly sworn, states:
I am the custodian of records for the above-referenced facility. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 24-9- 902(11)(12), the attached documents are true and accurate copies of records that contain acts, events, conditions, opinions, and/or diagnoses made at or near the time of the described acts, events, conditions, opinions and/or diagnoses, made by, or from information transmitted by, a person with personal knowledge and a business duty to report. The aforementioned records are kept in the course of a regularly conducted business activity, and it was the regular practice of this business activity to make the memorandum, report, record, or data compilation.
This Certificate of Authentication of Records is given pursuant to O.C.G.A § 24-9-902 (11)(12) in lieu of the personal appearance of the person certifying hereto, and in connection with a lawsuit involving Frank Ward filed in the State of Georgia.
The undersigned certifies that same is Records Custodian and is a person responsible for the keeping of records for Brooks Rehabilitation Hospital and that the within and attached records are true and accurate reproductions and copies of the records of this facility concerning Frank Ward which were kept in the aforesaid facility, and that said records were kept as reasonably for the act(s), event(s) or condition(s) concerning Frank Ward.
That any and all copies of records and documents attached hereto are true and correct copies of business records of Frank Ward and were kept in the ordinary course of business and that the facts represented in the written records were entered upon the records shortly after the incidents which they purports to reflect as part of the normal course of business.
The undersigned further certifies that said records with this attached Certificate were delivered pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 9-11-34(c)(2), directly to or to the agent of Kristen Cesario, MMPO Defense - Georgia, PO Box 52979, Atlanta, GA 30355, Attorney of Records for Defendant, who is the counsel who sought production.

answers.main_question: Brief synopsis/Medical care summary
answers.answer: The patient, Frank Ward, a 53-year-old male, was admitted on 2/17/2023 and discharged on 5/3/2023 following a complex ICU course. He underwent a decompressive craniectomy for brainstem compression due to an acute R MCA M1 occlusion and experienced complications including pneumonia (MSSA, MRSA, pseudomonas), acute renal failure requiring dialysis (resolved by 4/7/2023), anemia from procedural bleeding, and recurrent asystole and bradycardia episodes. Management included tracheostomy, PEG placement, dialysis, antibiotics, anticoagulation for DVTs, and cardiac monitoring. He was stabilized with improved renal function and transitioned to rehabilitation.
answers.raw_answer: The patient, Frank Ward, a 53-year-old male, was admitted on 2/17/2023 and discharged on 5/3/2023 following a complex ICU course. He underwent a decompressive craniectomy for brainstem compression due to an acute R MCA M1 occlusion and experienced complications including pneumonia (MSSA, MRSA, pseudomonas), acute renal failure requiring dialysis (resolved by 4/7/2023), anemia from procedural bleeding, and recurrent asystole and bradycardia episodes. Management included tracheostomy, PEG placement, dialysis, antibiotics, anticoagulation for DVTs, and cardiac monitoring. sources.chunk_preview: edema and he was taken urgently for a decompressive R craniectomy. He was brought back to ICU post-operatively. He failed a trial of extubation and underwent tracheostomy 3/10/23. Pulmonary will follo
sources.chunk_full:
edema and he was taken urgently for a decompressive R craniectomy. He was brought back to ICU post-operatively. He failed a trial of extubation and underwent tracheostomy 3/10/23. Pulmonary will follow for trach management.
His ICU course was complicated by pseudomonal and staphylococcal infections (both methicillin sensitive and resistant isolates). He has been on antibiotics and is currently on them for pneumonia. He has recently been febrile. He developed acute renal failure and was initiated on dialysis 3/27. Nephrology is following. On 4/11/2023 the patient had bleeding initially thought to be around the trach site. Ultimately was found that it was coming from the site of his IVC filter placement and a suture was placed and was transfused for a hgb of 5.6. Bleeding has now stabilized. He was briefly in step-down but was transition back to the ICU Patient was re-initiated on sedation and mechanical ventilation as he became lethargic during all this. Per ICU notes patient became bradycardic but rebounded without intervention. At approximately 8am this morning the patient had a long asystole arrest. Responded to atropine. He again had an asystole arrest at 10am requiring brief CPR. He was again given atropine. His sedation has been weaned as able. He is currently normal sinus rhythm on telemetry. He has had episodes of junctional bradycardia as well as brief Mobitz type 2 today. Cardiology has been asked to consult because of this.
Problem List
. Asystole Arrest / Junctional Bradycardia / Brief Mobitz II
· Acute anemia - Multifactorial - Transferred to ICU 2/2 bleeding / transfused
· Acute R MCA M1 occlusion
· Brainstem compression status post decompressive craniectomy
· Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure - Trach in place - on Vent
. Dysphagia - PEG in place
. R basilar pneumonia - MSSA, MRSA and pseudomonas
· Pleural effusion, right - exudative - parapneumonic
· DMII
. Dysphagia with PEG
· AKI on HD - Improving
. LUE DVT on Eliquis
· HTN / HLD
· BMI 35.44
Printed on 4/16/24 1028

answers.main_question: Alleged injury/Medical terms related to injury
answers.answer: The alleged injury and related medical terms include: - Right-sided craniotomy with bone flap removal and left-sided hemiparesis. - Hemiparesis of the left dominant side as a late effect of cerebral infarction. - Cerebrovascular accident (CVA), unspecified mechanism. - Acute pain in knees and chronic left shoulder pain. - Risk of injury and perioperative injury care.
answers.raw_answer:
The alleged injury and related medical terms include:  
- Right-sided craniotomy with bone flap removal and left-sided hemiparesis. [Sources: Document 1, Document 2]  
- Hemiparesis of the left dominant side as a late effect of cerebral infarction. [Source: Document 3]  
- Cerebrovascular accident (CVA), unspecified mechanism. [Source: Document 3]  
- Acute pain in knees and chronic left shoulder pain. [Source: Document 3]  
- Risk of injury and perioperative injury care. [Source: Document 5]

Medications:
-At this time, it appears appropriate for the patient's PCP to continue prescribing Norco 5-325mg Q6H PRN and oxycodone 10mg BID PRN as long as there is compliance with AB 474. These medications help improve the patient's pain and ability to perform ADLs and progress with physical therapy. The patient is at low risk for narcotic abuse. -Okay to continue Robaxin which is helping with the patient's pain
Interventions:
- Trigger point injections under ultrasound guidance with steroid given partial relief with trigger point injections with local anesthetic. The risks, benefits, and alternatives to this procedure were discussed and the patient wishes to proceed with the procedure. Risks include but are not limited to damage to surrounding structures, infection, bleeding, worsening of pain which can be permanent, and collapsed lung. Benefits include pain relief and improved function. Alternatives include not doing the procedure.
-I have discussed that at this time, I do not think that a left shoulder injection or knee injections would significantly improve the patient's pain given the lack of significant degenerative changes on his x-ray.
Follow-up: Next available for trigger point injections with steroid

answers.main_question: Summary of allegations
answers.answer: The allegations state that Frank Ward suffered severe brain damage due to delays in recognizing and treating a brain bleed and swelling after a stroke, despite noted neurological decline. The defendants, including hospital staff and affiliated entities, are accused of professional negligence for failing to provide timely and appropriate care, resulting in Mr. Ward requiring lifelong care and suffering significant physical and emotional harm. His wife, Rachael Ward, claims loss of companionship and services.
answers.raw_answer: The allegations state that Frank Ward suffered severe brain damage due to delays in recognizing and treating a brain bleed and swelling after a stroke, despite noted neurological decline. The defendants, including hospital staff and affiliated entities, are accused of professional negligence for failing to provide timely and appropriate care, resulting in Mr. Ward requiring lifelong care and suffering significant physical and emotional harm. His wife, Rachael Ward, claims loss of companionship and services. [Sources: Documents 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

JURY TRIAL DEMANDED
COMPLAINT FOR DAMAGES
COME NOW Frank Ward, Jr. and Rachael Ward ("Plaintiffs") and bring this Complaint for Damages by showing the Court and Jury as follows:
Introduction
1.
Plaintiff Frank Ward suffered a stroke. The neurological team at Savannah Memorial Hospital performed a thrombectomy, and Mr. Ward was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU). Mr. Ward's condition stabilized and his motor, cognitive and verbal function improved. Mr. Ward was discharged from the ICU to the main floor of the Hospital, where he was supposed to be
1
)
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
- Clerk of Court
7
3
frequently monitored for signs of neurological decline and treated appropriately. One of the known risk factors following a stroke like Mr. Ward had is swelling of the brain which will result in further brain damage if not recognized and promptly treated. While on the Hospital floor, Mr. Ward declined in verbal, cognitive and motor function which multiple providers noted, but failed to take appropriate action. After Mr. Ward started to decline, he had an MRI of his brain. The MRI showed a recent and evolving brain bleed which would explain Mr. Ward's decline and required immediate attention. Still, the Hospital did nothing. More than 30 hours after Mr. Ward's MRI exam, he had a CT Scan of his head, confirming a brain bleed and compression of his brainstem as a result of brain swelling. As a result of Defendants' delays, Mr. Ward suffered severe brain damage. Mr. Ward now requires around-the-clock care as a result of Defendants' lack of proper care.
Parties, Jurisdiction and Venue
2.
Plaintiffs Frank Ward and Rachael Ward reside in Sparks, Nevada. Plaintiffs subject themselves to the jurisdiction and venue of this Court.
3.

While on the Hospital floor, Mr. Ward declined in verbal, cognitive and motor function which multiple providers noted, but failed to take appropriate action. After Mr. Ward started to decline, he had an MRI of his brain. The MRI showed a recent and evolving brain bleed which would explain Mr. Ward's decline and required immediate attention. Still, the Hospital did nothing. More than 30 hours after Mr. Ward's MRI exam, he had a CT Scan of his head, confirming a brain bleed and compression of his brainstem as a result of brain swelling. As a result of Defendants' delays, Mr. Ward suffered severe brain damage. Mr. Ward now requires around-the-clock care as a result of Defendants' lack of proper care.
Parties, Jurisdiction and Venue
2.
Plaintiffs Frank Ward and Rachael Ward reside in Sparks, Nevada. Plaintiffs subject themselves to the jurisdiction and venue of this Court.
3.

sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.
14
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
> wiwo - Clerk of Court
62
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mr. Ward has incurred and continues to incur medical expenses, has lost and continues to lose wages, has suffered and continues to suffer severe pain, mental anguish, fear, shock and horror of his condition, loss of use of his body, loss of enjoyment of life, severe impairment of health and vigor physically and mentally, permanent disfigurement, loss of capacity to labor, physical confinement, and other harms and losses entitling Plaintiff Mr. Ward to compensation in an amount to be determined by the enlightened consciousness of a jury.
63.
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mrs. Ward has lost the society, companionship, and services of her husband.
Count I: Professional Negligence (All Defendants)
64.

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: on which multiple providers noted, but failed to take appropriate action. After Mr. Ward started to decline, he had an MRI of his brain. The MRI showed a recent and evolving brain bleed which would ex
sources.chunk_full:
on which multiple providers noted, but failed to take appropriate action. After Mr. Ward started to decline, he had an MRI of his brain. The MRI showed a recent and evolving brain bleed which would explain Mr. Ward's decline and required immediate attention. Still, the Hospital did nothing. More than 30 hours after Mr. Ward's MRI exam, he had a CT Scan of his head, confirming a brain bleed and compression of his brainstem as a result of brain swelling. As a result of Defendants' delays, Mr. Ward suffered severe brain damage. Mr. Ward now requires around-the-clock care as a result of Defendants' lack of proper care.
Parties, Jurisdiction and Venue
2.
Plaintiffs Frank Ward and Rachael Ward reside in Sparks, Nevada. Plaintiffs subject themselves to the jurisdiction and venue of this Court.
3.
Defendant Savannah Health Services, LLC d/b/a Memorial Health University Medical Center ("Memorial Health") owns and operates a hospital ("Hospital") located at 4700 Waters Ave., Savannah, Chatham County, Georgia 31404. Memorial Health is part of a provider network and subsidiary of HCA Healthcare and as such has its principal place of business located at One Park Plaza, Nashville, Tennessee 37203. Defendant Memorial Health may be served with process upon its registered agent The Corporation Company at 410 Peachtree Parkway Suite 4245, Cumming, Forsyth County, Georgia 30041.
2
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
1
1
1
- Clerk of Court
4.
Defendant Brittany Roy, RN ("Nurse Roy") is a registered nurse and resident of Liberty County, Georgia. She may be served with process at the following address: 49 Liberty Woods Dr., Fort Stewart, Georgia 31315.
5.
At all times material hereto, Defendant Nurse Roy was an employee, agent and/or ostensible agent of Defendant Memorial Health and was acting within the course and scope of her employment and/or agency with Memorial Health. As such, Memorial Health is liable to Plaintiffs under respondeat superior and/or agency theories for her negligent actions.
6.
Defendant Nephettia Robinson, RN ("Nurse Robinson") is a registered nurse and resident of Effingham County, Georgia. She may be served with process at the following address: 207 Moultrie Dr., Rincon, Georgia 31326.
7.
At all times material hereto, Defendant Nurse Robinson was an employee, agent and/or ostensible agent of Defendant Memorial Health and was acting within the course and scope of her employment and/or agency with Memorial Health. As such, Memorial Health is liable to Plaintiffs under respondeat superior and/or agency theories for her negligent actions.
8.
Defendant Rachel Tinker, RN ("Nurse Tinker") is a registered nurse and resident of Chatham County, Georgia. She may be served with process at the following address: 8 Elmwood Pl., Savannah, Georgia 31419.
3

Ouimad - Clerk of Court
9.
At all times material hereto, Defendant Nurse Tinker was an employee, agent and/or ostensible agent of Defendant Memorial Health and was acting within the course and scope of her employment and/or agency with Memorial Health. As such, Memorial Health is liable to Plaintiffs under respondeat superior and/or agency theories for her negligent actions.
10.
Defendant Sound Inpatient Physicians, Inc.'s ("Sound Physicians") principal place of business is located at 120 Brentwood Commons Way, Suite 510, Brentwood, Tennessee 37027. Defendant Sound Physicians may be served with process upon its registered agent Corporation Service Company at 2 Sun Court, Suite 400, Peachtree Corners, Gwinnett County, Georgia 30092. 11.
Defendant Everette Thombs, Jr., M.D. ("Dr. Thombs") is a physician and resident of Chatham County, Georgia. He may be served with process at the following address: 126 Goette Trl, Savannah, Georgia 31410.
12.
At all times material hereto, Defendant Dr. Thombs was an employee, agent and/or ostensible agent of Defendant Sound Physicians and was acting within the course and scope of his employment and/or agency with Sound Physicians.

sources.chunk_preview: nues to incur medical expenses, has lost and continues to lose wages, has suffered and continues to suffer severe pain, mental anguish, fear, shock and horror of his condition, loss of use of his body
sources.chunk_full:
nues to incur medical expenses, has lost and continues to lose wages, has suffered and continues to suffer severe pain, mental anguish, fear, shock and horror of his condition, loss of use of his body, loss of enjoyment of life, severe impairment of health and vigor physically and mentally, permanent disfigurement, loss of capacity to labor, physical confinement, and other harms and losses entitling Plaintiff Mr. Ward to compensation in an amount to be determined by the enlightened consciousness of a jury.
63.
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mrs. Ward has lost the society, companionship, and services of her husband.
Count I: Professional Negligence (All Defendants)
64.
Plaintiffs incorporate the paragraphs above as if fully restated herein.
65.
Defendant Nurse Robinson held herself out to the public as a registered nurse competent to provide care and treatment within the standard of care and owed a duty to exercise that degree of care and skill ordinarily exercised by health care providers, generally, under like conditions and similar surrounding circumstances as those presented by Mr. Ward.
66.
Nurse Robinson was negligent and deviated from the standard of care ordinarily exercised by nurses under like conditions and similar surrounding circumstances by failing to perform any neurological assessments from 4:00p.m. on February 24 through 8:00a.m. on February 25, 2023,
15
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
1
1
- Clerk of Court
failing to inform a physician of Mr. Ward's change in condition on the morning of February 25, 2023, and failing to inform a physician that Mr. Ward was no longer speaking and that the family was requesting a CT scan during the evening of February 26, 2023.
67.
Defendant Nurse Tinker held herself out to the public as a registered nurse competent to provide care and treatment within the standard of care and owed a duty to exercise that degree of care and skill ordinarily exercised by health care providers, generally, under like conditions and similar surrounding circumstances as those presented by Mr. Ward.
68.
Nurse Tinker was negligent and deviated from the standard of care ordinarily exercised by nurses under like conditions and similar surrounding circumstances by failing to inform a physician of Mr. Ward's change in condition following her neurological assessment on February 25, 2023.
69.
Defendant Nurse Roy held herself out to the public as a registered nurse competent to provide care and treatment within the standard of care and owed a duty to exercise that degree of care and skill ordinarily exercised by health care providers, generally, under like conditions and similar surrounding circumstances as those presented by Mr. Ward.
70
Nurse Roy was negligent and deviated from the standard of care ordinarily exercised by nurses under like conditions and similar surrounding circumstances by (i) failing to inform a physician of Mr. Ward's change in condition following her neurological assessment on February
16
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
wind - Clerk of Court
26, 2023 and (ii) failing to transport or have Mr. Ward transported to imaging for a CT scan immediately after a STAT CT scan was ordered on February 27, 2023.
71.
Memorial Health is vicariously liable to Plaintiffs under the doctrine of respondeat superior and/or principles of agency law for all injuries and damages caused by their employees and/or agents including, but not limited to, Nurse Robinson and Nurse Roy and other medical providers responsible for Mr. Ward's care.
72.
Defendant Dr. Thombs held himself out to the public as a physician competent to provide care and treatment within the standard of care and owed a duty to exercise that degree of care and skill ordinarily exercised by health care providers, generally, under like conditions and similar surrounding circumstances as those presented by Mr. Ward.
73.
Dr.

answers.section_name: OVERVIEW AND TIMELINE OF KEY POINTS
answers.main_question: If Yes, what information was missing or incorrect? If no timeline was provided, please include a timeline outlining the key medical events relevant to this case and this defendant.
Based on your review, please describe the injury the patient incurred:
answers.answer: The patient suffered a right-sided craniectomy due to a massive right middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke, resulting in left-sided hemiparesis. Imaging also revealed a slightly displaced osteochondral fragment at the lateral femoral condyle, mild osteoarthritis in both knees, and mild AC joint osteoarthritis with subluxation of the left humeral head.
answers.raw_answer: The patient suffered a right-sided craniectomy due to a massive right middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke, resulting in left-sided hemiparesis. Imaging also revealed a slightly displaced osteochondral fragment at the lateral femoral condyle, mild osteoarthritis in both knees, and mild AC joint osteoarthritis with subluxation of the left humeral head. [Sources: Document 1, Document 2, Document 4, Document 5]

sources.chunk_preview: overlying tissue and the dura. There was an area posteriorly where we could see clear fluid through a small dural defect. We worked with the sharp reflection of the skin flap off of the dura as well a
sources.chunk_full:
overlying tissue and the dura. There was an area posteriorly where we could see clear fluid through a small dural defect. We worked with the sharp reflection of the skin flap off of the dura as well as using Metzenbaum scissors. Once we had elevated the skin flap and had circumferentially exposed the bone edges from the skull we irrigated copiously with antibiotic saline. We then placed 2 dural tack-up sutures. We placed a large piece of DuraGen. We had placed bone flap in antibiotic laden saline. We placed the bone flap and it fit nicely. There was no undue pressure on the underlying brain. We then placed our cranial plates using 2 burr hole covers and 1 sq plate. These were attached with the 4-0 screws. We then anchored the bone flap back to the patient's skull using 4-0 titanium screws. We had placed the dural tack-up holes in the bone flap. Tack-up sutures were then secured. We irrigated copiously with antibiotic laden saline. The skull flap was at least 16 x 20 cm.
A JP drain was placed and brought out through separate stab incision. The wound was then closed in an interrupted fashion with sutures and then the skin with staples. A sterile dressing was applied.
The surgical assistant was present throughout the case and assisted with all aspects of the case including but not limited to the exposure, retraction, microdissection, hemostasis, irrigation and the closure during the entire case.
The patient tolerated the procedure without obvious complication. The instrument and sponge count was correct. Patient was extubated per the anesthesia service and taken to the recovery room in stable condition.
Counts: Needle, sponge and instrument counts were correct.

answers.main_question: Please select the degree of injury alleged and the degree of injury suffered. In the event a patient has multiple injuries, rate the most severe injury and discuss any other injury in Question 'C' below. As a reminder, be objective and avoid hindsight bias. Your rating of the degree of injury should not be influenced by your opinions of the quality of care or causation and vice versa.

raw_answer.alleged:
RATING: 8. Most significant injuries where patient survives but has fatal prognosis or requires lifelong care: severe brain damage; CP; quadriplegia; major burns; failure to diagnose cancer with evidence of spread and a poor prognosis, etc. OR a neurological injury resulting in being bedridden, incontinent and requiring constant nursing care and attention.

EXPLANATION: The plaintiff alleges severe neurological injury resulting from a massive right MCA stroke, leading to left-sided hemiparesis and significant functional impairments. The patient requires an electric wheelchair, Hoyer lift for transfers, and exhibits flaccid motor response and no movement in the left upper and lower extremities, indicating severe disability. These findings align with a neurological injury necessitating constant care and assistance. [Sources: Document 1, Document 2, Document 3, Document 4, Document 5]
raw_answer.suffered:
**RATING: 8. Most significant injuries where patient survives but has fatal prognosis or requires lifelong care: severe brain damage; CP; quadriplegia; major burns; failure to diagnose cancer with evidence of spread and a poor prognosis, etc. OR a neurological injury resulting in being bedridden, incontinent and requiring constant nursing care and attention.**

**EXPLANATION:** The patient suffered a massive right middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke, which necessitated a right-sided craniectomy and later replacement of the bone flap. The stroke resulted in left-sided hemiparesis (partial paralysis) and significant neurological deficits, including no motor function in the left upper and lower extremities (LUE and LLE) and absent left hand grip strength. The patient requires a Hoyer lift for transfers and is dependent on an electric wheelchair for mobility, indicating severe physical and neurological impairments. Additionally, the patient has other injuries, including a slightly displaced osteochondral fragment at the lateral femoral condyle, mild osteoarthritis in both knees, and mild AC joint osteoarthritis with subluxation of the left humeral head. These findings collectively indicate a severe, permanent injury requiring lifelong care and assistance with activities of daily living. [Sources: Document 1, Document 2, Document 3, Document 4, Document 5]

answers.main_question: Please discuss the impact the injury will have on the patient and/or Plaintiff.
answers.answer: The injury will significantly impact the patient's mobility, daily activities, and coping mechanisms. The patient requires education on managing the affected extremity, including limiting pressure on the affected side, supporting it during repositioning, and protecting it from extreme temperatures. Mobility challenges include the need to watch the affected leg while walking, use safety belts, and transfer toward the unaffected side. Additionally, the patient may need inpatient rehabilitation for further recovery.
answers.raw_answer: The injury will significantly impact the patient's mobility, daily activities, and coping mechanisms. The patient requires education on managing the affected extremity, including limiting pressure on the affected side, supporting it during repositioning, and protecting it from extreme temperatures. Mobility challenges include the need to watch the affected leg while walking, use safety belts, and transfer toward the unaffected side. Additionally, the patient may need inpatient rehabilitation for further recovery. [Sources: Documents 1, 2, 5]

answers.main_question: Did the defendant fail to assess the patient within an appropriate timeframe?
answers.raw_answer: Yes. There were no documented nursing neurological assessments for Mr. Ward from 4:00 p.m. on February 24, 2023, through 8:00 a.m. on February 25, 2023, despite his condition requiring periodic neurological checks every four hours. [Source: Document 1, Document 2]

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview:
emorial, Mr. Ward was taken for an urgent thrombectomy of the right middle cerebral artery. As a result of the thrombectomy, Mr. Ward had reported improved blood flow.
22.
Following the thrombectomy,
sources.chunk_full:
emorial, Mr. Ward was taken for an urgent thrombectomy of the right middle cerebral artery. As a result of the thrombectomy, Mr. Ward had reported improved blood flow.
22.
Following the thrombectomy, Mr. Ward was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit ("ICU") for continued monitoring and a higher level of care.
23.
One concern for patients who have suffered stroke is brain swelling that often occurs as a consequence of the stroke. If the brain swells too much, the swelling will cause further injury and possible hemorrhage to the brain.
24.
To control the swelling, Plaintiff's treating neurosurgeon, Dr. Daniel Suh, ordered a 3% saline solution which was delivered to Mr. Ward starting on February 19, 2023.
25.
6
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
د ....
- Clerk of Court
Furthermore, on February 17, 2023, an order was entered by Kathleen Humkey, MD to perform neurological checks every hour.
26.
Between February 17 and February 23, 2023, Mr. Ward's physical, cognitive, and verbal condition improved.
27
On February 23, 2023 at 2:14a.m., a CT scan of Mr. Ward's showed "evolving large right MCA subacute infarct with stable mass effect and leftward midline shift of 5 mm, stable."
28.
At 11:06a.m., Dr. Osman Perez noted that Mr. Ward had a stable neurological exam and a stable CT scan. He further noted that Mr. Ward's best verbal response was "oriented", and his best motor response was "obeys commands." He also noted that an MRI was pending.
29.
At 11:23a.m., Dr. Suh noted that Mr. Ward's repeat CT scan was "stable with minimal shift no change." His plan was to continue with aggressive ICU care with 3% hypertonic saline and to slowly taper the hypertonic saline so his sodium could start to trend down.
30
On February 24, 2023, at 2:38a.m., a CT scan showed "Large subacute right MCA territory infarct is again noted with stable mass effect and leftward midline shift of 5 mm, previously 5 mm." The impression was again noted as stable.
31
At 10:49a.m. on February 24, 2023, Mr. Ward was discharged from the ICU to the internal medicine service on the medical floor of the Hospital (the "floor").
7
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
Jiwa - Clerk of Court
32.
Before being discharged to the floor, Mr. Ward's saline therapy was discontinued.
33.
From 6:00a.m. until 4:00pm. on February 24, 2023, the nursing flowsheets all indicate the following:
Eye Opening: Spontaneous Best Verbal Response: Oriented Best Motor Response: Obeys Commands Glasgow Coma Scale: 15
34.
At 5:49p.m. on February 24, 2023, Rachel Tinker, RN signed an order that was authorized by Thomas Allen, PA to perform neurological checks every four hours from February 24, 2023 at 8:00p.m. until otherwise specified.
35.
Periodic neurological checks were necessary since Mr. Ward remained at risk for brain swelling, subsequent stroke or other adverse neurological events. A decline in motor, verbal or cognitive ability would be a sign that Mr. Ward required immediate medical attention and warrant additional diagnostic imaging, such as a CT Scan, to rule out additional brain injury as a cause of the decline.
36.
At 7:28p.m. on February 24, 2023, Dr. Suh noted that Mr. Ward was stable overnight and was moved to the floor. He indicated that the repeat CT scan from that morning was "stable with minimal shift no change." His neurological exam noted the following: "sleeping but arouses. Left hemiplegia. States name and following commands briskly on the right."
8
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
Jiwa - Clerk of Court
37.
There were no documented nursing neurological assessments from 4:00p.m. on February 24, 2023 through 8:00a.m. on February 25, 2023.
38.
At 8:00a.m. on February 25, 2023, the nursing assessment was as follows:
Eye Opening: To Sound Best Verbal Response: Confused Best Motor Response: Obeys Commands Glasgow Coma Scale: 13
39.
Despite this decline in Mr. Ward's neurological exam from the day before, the nurses did not inform any physicians regarding Mr.

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.
14
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
> wiwo - Clerk of Court
62
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mr. Ward has incurred and continues to incur medical expenses, has lost and continues to lose wages, has suffered and continues to suffer severe pain, mental anguish, fear, shock and horror of his condition, loss of use of his body, loss of enjoyment of life, severe impairment of health and vigor physically and mentally, permanent disfigurement, loss of capacity to labor, physical confinement, and other harms and losses entitling Plaintiff Mr. Ward to compensation in an amount to be determined by the enlightened consciousness of a jury.
63.
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mrs. Ward has lost the society, companionship, and services of her husband.
Count I: Professional Negligence (All Defendants)
64.
Plaintiffs incorporate the paragraphs above as if fully restated herein.
65.

answers.main_question: Was this a deviation from acceptable practice?
answers.raw_answer: Yes. The defendant's failure to perform timely neurological assessments and notify physicians of the patient's condition changes on February 24-26, 2023, deviated from the standard of care expected in such circumstances. [Sources: Document 3, Document 4, Document 5]

sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.

answers.main_question: Did it likely impact the patient’s care or outcome?
answers.raw_answer: Yes. The delay in assessment and treatment contributed to the patient's brain herniation, subsequent hemicraniectomy, and long-term complications, as detailed in the documents. [Sources: Document 1, Document 3, Document 4]

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.
14
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
> wiwo - Clerk of Court
62
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mr. Ward has incurred and continues to incur medical expenses, has lost and continues to lose wages, has suffered and continues to suffer severe pain, mental anguish, fear, shock and horror of his condition, loss of use of his body, loss of enjoyment of life, severe impairment of health and vigor physically and mentally, permanent disfigurement, loss of capacity to labor, physical confinement, and other harms and losses entitling Plaintiff Mr. Ward to compensation in an amount to be determined by the enlightened consciousness of a jury.
63.
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mrs. Ward has lost the society, companionship, and services of her husband.
Count I: Professional Negligence (All Defendants)
64.
Plaintiffs incorporate the paragraphs above as if fully restated herein.
65.

These findings required timely medical attention, and a delay in assessment could have exacerbated the patient's condition.

The material shall include without limitation, correspondence, memorandum, stenographic and handwritten notes, studies, publications, books, pamphlets, voice recording, reports, minutes, telegrams, telexes, memoranda of agreement, diaries, calendars, invoices, bills, summaries, checks, wage histories, employment contracts, personnel file and medical records. emorial, Mr. Ward was taken for an urgent thrombectomy of the right middle cerebral artery. As a result of the thrombectomy, Mr. Ward had reported improved blood flow.

sources.chunk_full:
emorial, Mr. Ward was taken for an urgent thrombectomy of the right middle cerebral artery. As a result of the thrombectomy, Mr. Ward had reported improved blood flow.
22.
Following the thrombectomy, Mr. Ward was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit ("ICU") for continued monitoring and a higher level of care.
23.
One concern for patients who have suffered stroke is brain swelling that often occurs as a consequence of the stroke. If the brain swells too much, the swelling will cause further injury and possible hemorrhage to the brain.
24.
To control the swelling, Plaintiff's treating neurosurgeon, Dr. Daniel Suh, ordered a 3% saline solution which was delivered to Mr. Ward starting on February 19, 2023.
25.
6
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
د ....
- Clerk of Court
Furthermore, on February 17, 2023, an order was entered by Kathleen Humkey, MD to perform neurological checks every hour.
26.
Between February 17 and February 23, 2023, Mr. Ward's physical, cognitive, and verbal condition improved.
27
On February 23, 2023 at 2:14a.m., a CT scan of Mr. Ward's showed "evolving large right MCA subacute infarct with stable mass effect and leftward midline shift of 5 mm, stable."
28.
At 11:06a.m., Dr. Osman Perez noted that Mr. Ward had a stable neurological exam and a stable CT scan. He further noted that Mr. Ward's best verbal response was "oriented", and his best motor response was "obeys commands." He also noted that an MRI was pending.
29.
At 11:23a.m., Dr. Suh noted that Mr. Ward's repeat CT scan was "stable with minimal shift no change." His plan was to continue with aggressive ICU care with 3% hypertonic saline and to slowly taper the hypertonic saline so his sodium could start to trend down.
30
On February 24, 2023, at 2:38a.m., a CT scan showed "Large subacute right MCA territory infarct is again noted with stable mass effect and leftward midline shift of 5 mm, previously 5 mm." The impression was again noted as stable.
31
At 10:49a.m. on February 24, 2023, Mr. Ward was discharged from the ICU to the internal medicine service on the medical floor of the Hospital (the "floor").
7
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
Jiwa - Clerk of Court
32.
Before being discharged to the floor, Mr. Ward's saline therapy was discontinued.
33.
From 6:00a.m. until 4:00pm. on February 24, 2023, the nursing flowsheets all indicate the following:
Eye Opening: Spontaneous Best Verbal Response: Oriented Best Motor Response: Obeys Commands Glasgow Coma Scale: 15
34.
At 5:49p.m. on February 24, 2023, Rachel Tinker, RN signed an order that was authorized by Thomas Allen, PA to perform neurological checks every four hours from February 24, 2023 at 8:00p.m. until otherwise specified.
35.
Periodic neurological checks were necessary since Mr. Ward remained at risk for brain swelling, subsequent stroke or other adverse neurological events. A decline in motor, verbal or cognitive ability would be a sign that Mr. Ward required immediate medical attention and warrant additional diagnostic imaging, such as a CT Scan, to rule out additional brain injury as a cause of the decline.
36.
At 7:28p.m. on February 24, 2023, Dr. Suh noted that Mr. Ward was stable overnight and was moved to the floor. He indicated that the repeat CT scan from that morning was "stable with minimal shift no change." His neurological exam noted the following: "sleeping but arouses. Left hemiplegia. States name and following commands briskly on the right."
8
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
Jiwa - Clerk of Court
37.
There were no documented nursing neurological assessments from 4:00p.m. on February 24, 2023 through 8:00a.m. on February 25, 2023.
38.
At 8:00a.m. on February 25, 2023, the nursing assessment was as follows:
Eye Opening: To Sound Best Verbal Response: Confused Best Motor Response: Obeys Commands Glasgow Coma Scale: 13
39.
Despite this decline in Mr. Ward's neurological exam from the day before, the nurses did not inform any physicians regarding Mr.

)(12), the attached documents are true and accurate copies of records that contain acts, events, conditions, opinions, and/or diagnoses made at or near the time of the described acts, events, conditions, opinions and/or diagnoses, made by, or from information transmitted by, a person with personal knowledge and a business duty to report. The aforementioned records are kept in the course of a regularly conducted business activity, and it was the regular practice of this business activity to make the memorandum, report, record, or data compilation.
This Certificate of Authentication of Records is given pursuant to O.C.G.A § 24-9-902 (11)(12) in lieu of the personal appearance of the person certifying hereto, and in connection with a lawsuit involving Frank Ward filed in the State of Georgia.
The undersigned certifies that same is Records Custodian and is a person responsible for the keeping of records for Brooks Rehabilitation Hospital and that the within and attached records are true and accurate reproductions and copies of the records of this facility concerning Frank Ward which were kept in the aforesaid facility, and that said records were kept as reasonably for the act(s), event(s) or condition(s) concerning Frank Ward.
That any and all copies of records and documents attached hereto are true and correct copies of business records of Frank Ward and were kept in the ordinary course of business and that the facts represented in the written records were entered upon the records shortly after the incidents which they purports to reflect as part of the normal course of business.
The undersigned further certifies that said records with this attached Certificate were delivered pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 9-11-34(c)(2), directly to or to the agent of Kristen Cesario, MMPO Defense - Georgia, PO Box 52979, Atlanta, GA 30355, Attorney of Records for Defendant, who is the counsel who sought production.

answers.main_question: If Yes or Unclear, what information was missed or overlooked?
answers.answer: The defendant missed or overlooked changes in Mr. Ward's neurological status and imaging findings. Specifically: - No action was taken despite a significant increase in leftward midline shift noted in the MRI on 2/26/2023. - Neurological assessments were not documented between 4:00 p.m. on 2/24/2023 and 8:00 a.m. on 2/25/2023, despite the patient being at risk for brain swelling and other adverse events. - A decline in the Glasgow Coma Scale score on 2/25/2023 was not reported to physicians. These omissions delayed necessary medical interventions.
answers.raw_answer:
The defendant missed or overlooked changes in Mr. Ward's neurological status and imaging findings. Specifically:  

- No action was taken despite a significant increase in leftward midline shift noted in the MRI on 2/26/2023. [Source: Document 3]  
- Neurological assessments were not documented between 4:00 p.m. on 2/24/2023 and 8:00 a.m. on 2/25/2023, despite the patient being at risk for brain swelling and other adverse events. [Source: Document 5]  
- A decline in the Glasgow Coma Scale score on 2/25/2023 was not reported to physicians. [Source: Document 5]  

These omissions delayed necessary medical interventions.

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.
14
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
> wiwo - Clerk of Court
62
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mr. Ward has incurred and continues to incur medical expenses, has lost and continues to lose wages, has suffered and continues to suffer severe pain, mental anguish, fear, shock and horror of his condition, loss of use of his body, loss of enjoyment of life, severe impairment of health and vigor physically and mentally, permanent disfigurement, loss of capacity to labor, physical confinement, and other harms and losses entitling Plaintiff Mr. Ward to compensation in an amount to be determined by the enlightened consciousness of a jury.
63.
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mrs. Ward has lost the society, companionship, and services of her husband.
Count I: Professional Negligence (All Defendants)
64.
Plaintiffs incorporate the paragraphs above as if fully restated herein.
65.
