sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: T to STAT in the system RN informed wife and said transport would be there soon. RN checked on other patients. When the neurosurgeon asked for RN and asked why patient had not been down to CT yet, RN
sources.chunk_full:
T to STAT in the system RN informed wife and said transport would be there soon. RN checked on other patients. When the neurosurgeon asked for RN and asked why patient had not been down to CT yet, RN informed surgeon that she was coming to ask where transport was because RN could not leave the floor due to having 6 other patients with varying acuity. A call was made down to transport about the severity of this and the urgency needed for patient. Charge nurse stepped in and transported patient down to CT with HUC. Patient then went to PACU and did not return to the floor. RN called and gave report to PACU nurse.
56.
At 1:32p.m. February 27, 2023, Dr. Suh began performing an emergent decompressive hemicraniectomy surgery.
57.
Surgery ended at 4:08p.m. and Mr. Ward was brought to the ICU.
58.
At 7:03p.m., Dr. Osman Perez, critical care physician in the ICU, documented the following in his interval history for Mr. Ward:
. Repeat head CT on 02/24 showed a stable exam with similar 5 mm shift.
. On 02/26 around 01:00 the patient was taken for MRI BATT which had been ordered as part of his initial stroke workup but had not been done due to patient clinical status. MRI BATT showed evolving large right MCA territory subacute infarction with regions of hemosiderin deposition with 1.2 cm of leftward midline shift. This was significantly increased leftward shift when compared to CT scan from 02/24. This was noted in the primary team's note, however no documentation about a change in mental status or plan for adjustment of treatment based on those findings.
. On 02/27 patient was reportedly still more somnolent so a CT head was ordered which showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles. It also showed conclusion of right MCA territory infarction with no lobar hemorrhage.
. Based on this imaging, neurosurgery decided to take the patient for right hemicraniectomy with placement of an ICP monitor. The plan is for the patient to remain intubated following the procedure. He also received a PICC line for 3% NS
59.
Following the hemicraniectomy surgery, Mr. Ward remained at Savannah Memorial until May 3, 2023, during which time, he experienced numerous complications, many of which were due to Hospital neglect. For instance, there were two occasions where Mr. Ward bled profusely
13
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
VINOS
- Clerk of Court
and most nearly bled out before receiving any medical attention. On the second occasion, Mr. Ward coded twice due to blood loss. His discharge summary described the following hospital course, including the second profuse bleeding event on April 12, 2023 where Mr. Ward was found covered in blood and which led to him suffering cardiac arrest.
53-year-old male with past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus who presented initially to an outside hospital with acute onset of left-sided weakness on 2/17/2023. OSH imaging revealed right M1 occlusion and patient received TNK at OSH. He was transferred to our facility for LVO thrombectomy with Interventional Radiology which was completed shortly after admission to our facility on 2/17/2023. Repeat imaging revealed significant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging.

emorial, Mr. Ward was taken for an urgent thrombectomy of the right middle cerebral artery. As a result of the thrombectomy, Mr. Ward had reported improved blood flow.
22.
Following the thrombectomy, Mr. Ward was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit ("ICU") for continued monitoring and a higher level of care.
23.
One concern for patients who have suffered stroke is brain swelling that often occurs as a consequence of the stroke. If the brain swells too much, the swelling will cause further injury and possible hemorrhage to the brain.
24.
To control the swelling, Plaintiff's treating neurosurgeon, Dr. Daniel Suh, ordered a 3% saline solution which was delivered to Mr. Ward starting on February 19, 2023.
25.
6
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
د ....
- Clerk of Court
Furthermore, on February 17, 2023, an order was entered by Kathleen Humkey, MD to perform neurological checks every hour.
26.
Between February 17 and February 23, 2023, Mr. Ward's physical, cognitive, and verbal condition improved.
27
On February 23, 2023 at 2:14a.m., a CT scan of Mr. Ward's showed "evolving large right MCA subacute infarct with stable mass effect and leftward midline shift of 5 mm, stable."
28.
At 11:06a.m., Dr. Osman Perez noted that Mr. Ward had a stable neurological exam and a stable CT scan. He further noted that Mr. Ward's best verbal response was "oriented", and his best motor response was "obeys commands." He also noted that an MRI was pending.
29.
At 11:23a.m., Dr. Suh noted that Mr. Ward's repeat CT scan was "stable with minimal shift no change." His plan was to continue with aggressive ICU care with 3% hypertonic saline and to slowly taper the hypertonic saline so his sodium could start to trend down.
30
On February 24, 2023, at 2:38a.m., a CT scan showed "Large subacute right MCA territory infarct is again noted with stable mass effect and leftward midline shift of 5 mm, previously 5 mm." The impression was again noted as stable.
31
At 10:49a.m. on February 24, 2023, Mr. Ward was discharged from the ICU to the internal medicine service on the medical floor of the Hospital (the "floor").
7

32.
Before being discharged to the floor, Mr. Ward's saline therapy was discontinued.
33.
From 6:00a.m. until 4:00pm. on February 24, 2023, the nursing flowsheets all indicate the following:
Eye Opening: Spontaneous Best Verbal Response: Oriented Best Motor Response: Obeys Commands Glasgow Coma Scale: 15
34.
At 5:49p.m. on February 24, 2023, Rachel Tinker, RN signed an order that was authorized by Thomas Allen, PA to perform neurological checks every four hours from February 24, 2023 at 8:00p.m. until otherwise specified.
35.
Periodic neurological checks were necessary since Mr. Ward remained at risk for brain swelling, subsequent stroke or other adverse neurological events. A decline in motor, verbal or cognitive ability would be a sign that Mr. Ward required immediate medical attention and warrant additional diagnostic imaging, such as a CT Scan, to rule out additional brain injury as a cause of the decline.
36.
At 7:28p.m. on February 24, 2023, Dr. Suh noted that Mr. Ward was stable overnight and was moved to the floor. He indicated that the repeat CT scan from that morning was "stable with minimal shift no change." His neurological exam noted the following: "sleeping but arouses. Left hemiplegia. States name and following commands briskly on the right."

answers.main_question: Was this a deviation from acceptable practice?
answers.raw_answer: Yes. Failing to review pertinent medical records, including historical and outside records, constitutes a deviation from the standard of care expected of healthcare providers. This failure contributed to delays in diagnosis and treatment, as noted in the documents. [Sources: Document 3, Document 4, Document 5]

sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.

sources.chunk_full:
T to STAT in the system RN informed wife and said transport would be there soon. RN checked on other patients. When the neurosurgeon asked for RN and asked why patient had not been down to CT yet, RN informed surgeon that she was coming to ask where transport was because RN could not leave the floor due to having 6 other patients with varying acuity. A call was made down to transport about the severity of this and the urgency needed for patient. Charge nurse stepped in and transported patient down to CT with HUC. Patient then went to PACU and did not return to the floor. RN called and gave report to PACU nurse.
56.
At 1:32p.m. February 27, 2023, Dr. Suh began performing an emergent decompressive hemicraniectomy surgery.
57.
Surgery ended at 4:08p.m. and Mr. Ward was brought to the ICU.
58.
At 7:03p.m., Dr. Osman Perez, critical care physician in the ICU, documented the following in his interval history for Mr. Ward:
. Repeat head CT on 02/24 showed a stable exam with similar 5 mm shift.
. On 02/26 around 01:00 the patient was taken for MRI BATT which had been ordered as part of his initial stroke workup but had not been done due to patient clinical status. MRI BATT showed evolving large right MCA territory subacute infarction with regions of hemosiderin deposition with 1.2 cm of leftward midline shift. This was significantly increased leftward shift when compared to CT scan from 02/24. This was noted in the primary team's note, however no documentation about a change in mental status or plan for adjustment of treatment based on those findings.
. On 02/27 patient was reportedly still more somnolent so a CT head was ordered which showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles. It also showed conclusion of right MCA territory infarction with no lobar hemorrhage.
. Based on this imaging, neurosurgery decided to take the patient for right hemicraniectomy with placement of an ICP monitor. The plan is for the patient to remain intubated following the procedure. He also received a PICC line for 3% NS
59.
Following the hemicraniectomy surgery, Mr. Ward remained at Savannah Memorial until May 3, 2023, during which time, he experienced numerous complications, many of which were due to Hospital neglect. For instance, there were two occasions where Mr. Ward bled profusely

53-year-old male with past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus who presented initially to an outside hospital with acute onset of left-sided weakness on 2/17/2023. OSH imaging revealed right M1 occlusion and patient received TNK at OSH. He was transferred to our facility for LVO thrombectomy with Interventional Radiology which was completed shortly after admission to our facility on 2/17/2023. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging.

Description: Advance Directives:
An advance healthcare directive may also be known as a living will. It is a legal document in which a person specifies what actions should be taken for their health if they are no longer able to make decisions for themselves due to illness.
Action: Refer patient and/or family to appropriate resource at facility if they wish to complete an advance healthcare directive and scan a copy of the directive into the chart.

Patient Education (continued)
Description: Review plan of care including provider roles, health history, IV and medications, labs and tests, and discharge planning. Take extra time to reiterate to patient that he/she may ask questions at any time and should always let staff know if he/she is having difficulty breathing, pain or any discomfort at any time.

answers.main_question: Did it likely impact the patient’s care or outcome?
answers.raw_answer: Yes. The failure to review pertinent medical records delayed recognition of worsening brain herniation and midline shift, leading to delayed surgical intervention and subsequent complications, including respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, and prolonged hospitalization. [Sources: Document 1, Document 2, Document 3]

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: T to STAT in the system RN informed wife and said transport would be there soon. RN checked on other patients. When the neurosurgeon asked for RN and asked why patient had not been down to CT yet, RN
sources.chunk_full:
T to STAT in the system RN informed wife and said transport would be there soon. RN checked on other patients. When the neurosurgeon asked for RN and asked why patient had not been down to CT yet, RN informed surgeon that she was coming to ask where transport was because RN could not leave the floor due to having 6 other patients with varying acuity. A call was made down to transport about the severity of this and the urgency needed for patient. Charge nurse stepped in and transported patient down to CT with HUC. Patient then went to PACU and did not return to the floor. RN called and gave report to PACU nurse.
56.
At 1:32p.m. February 27, 2023, Dr. Suh began performing an emergent decompressive hemicraniectomy surgery.
57.
Surgery ended at 4:08p.m. and Mr. Ward was brought to the ICU.
58.
At 7:03p.m., Dr. Osman Perez, critical care physician in the ICU, documented the following in his interval history for Mr. Ward:
. Repeat head CT on 02/24 showed a stable exam with similar 5 mm shift.
. On 02/26 around 01:00 the patient was taken for MRI BATT which had been ordered as part of his initial stroke workup but had not been done due to patient clinical status. MRI BATT showed evolving large right MCA territory subacute infarction with regions of hemosiderin deposition with 1.2 cm of leftward midline shift. This was significantly increased leftward shift when compared to CT scan from 02/24. This was noted in the primary team's note, however no documentation about a change in mental status or plan for adjustment of treatment based on those findings.
. On 02/27 patient was reportedly still more somnolent so a CT head was ordered which showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles. It also showed conclusion of right MCA territory infarction with no lobar hemorrhage.
. Based on this imaging, neurosurgery decided to take the patient for right hemicraniectomy with placement of an ICP monitor. The plan is for the patient to remain intubated following the procedure. He also received a PICC line for 3% NS
59.
Following the hemicraniectomy surgery, Mr. Ward remained at Savannah Memorial until May 3, 2023, during which time, he experienced numerous complications, many of which were due to Hospital neglect. For instance, there were two occasions where Mr. Ward bled profusely
13
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
VINOS
- Clerk of Court
and most nearly bled out before receiving any medical attention. On the second occasion, Mr. Ward coded twice due to blood loss. His discharge summary described the following hospital course, including the second profuse bleeding event on April 12, 2023 where Mr. Ward was found covered in blood and which led to him suffering cardiac arrest.
53-year-old male with past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus who presented initially to an outside hospital with acute onset of left-sided weakness on 2/17/2023. OSH imaging revealed right M1 occlusion and patient received TNK at OSH. He was transferred to our facility for LVO thrombectomy with Interventional Radiology which was completed shortly after admission to our facility on 2/17/2023. Repeat imaging revealed significant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging.

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.
14
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
> wiwo - Clerk of Court
62
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mr. Ward has incurred and continues to incur medical expenses, has lost and continues to lose wages, has suffered and continues to suffer severe pain, mental anguish, fear, shock and horror of his condition, loss of use of his body, loss of enjoyment of life, severe impairment of health and vigor physically and mentally, permanent disfigurement, loss of capacity to labor, physical confinement, and other harms and losses entitling Plaintiff Mr. Ward to compensation in an amount to be determined by the enlightened consciousness of a jury.
63.
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mrs. Ward has lost the society, companionship, and services of her husband.
Count I: Professional Negligence (All Defendants)
64.
Plaintiffs incorporate the paragraphs above as if fully restated herein.
65.

sources.chunk_preview: T to STAT in the system RN informed wife and said transport would be there soon. RN checked on other patients. When the neurosurgeon asked for RN and asked why patient had not been down to CT yet, RN
sources.chunk_full:
T to STAT in the system RN informed wife and said transport would be there soon. RN checked on other patients. When the neurosurgeon asked for RN and asked why patient had not been down to CT yet, RN informed surgeon that she was coming to ask where transport was because RN could not leave the floor due to having 6 other patients with varying acuity. A call was made down to transport about the severity of this and the urgency needed for patient. Charge nurse stepped in and transported patient down to CT with HUC. Patient then went to PACU and did not return to the floor. RN called and gave report to PACU nurse.
56.
At 1:32p.m. February 27, 2023, Dr. Suh began performing an emergent decompressive hemicraniectomy surgery.
57.
Surgery ended at 4:08p.m. and Mr. Ward was brought to the ICU.
58.
At 7:03p.m., Dr. Osman Perez, critical care physician in the ICU, documented the following in his interval history for Mr. Ward:
. Repeat head CT on 02/24 showed a stable exam with similar 5 mm shift.
. On 02/26 around 01:00 the patient was taken for MRI BATT which had been ordered as part of his initial stroke workup but had not been done due to patient clinical status. MRI BATT showed evolving large right MCA territory subacute infarction with regions of hemosiderin deposition with 1.2 cm of leftward midline shift. This was significantly increased leftward shift when compared to CT scan from 02/24. This was noted in the primary team's note, however no documentation about a change in mental status or plan for adjustment of treatment based on those findings.
. On 02/27 patient was reportedly still more somnolent so a CT head was ordered which showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles. It also showed conclusion of right MCA territory infarction with no lobar hemorrhage.
. Based on this imaging, neurosurgery decided to take the patient for right hemicraniectomy with placement of an ICP monitor. The plan is for the patient to remain intubated following the procedure. He also received a PICC line for 3% NS
59.
Following the hemicraniectomy surgery, Mr. Ward remained at Savannah Memorial until May 3, 2023, during which time, he experienced numerous complications, many of which were due to Hospital neglect. For instance, there were two occasions where Mr. Ward bled profusely
13
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
VINOS
- Clerk of Court
and most nearly bled out before receiving any medical attention. On the second occasion, Mr. Ward coded twice due to blood loss. His discharge summary described the following hospital course, including the second profuse bleeding event on April 12, 2023 where Mr. Ward was found covered in blood and which led to him suffering cardiac arrest.
53-year-old male with past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus who presented initially to an outside hospital with acute onset of left-sided weakness on 2/17/2023. OSH imaging revealed right M1 occlusion and patient received TNK at OSH. He was transferred to our facility for LVO thrombectomy with Interventional Radiology which was completed shortly after admission to our facility on 2/17/2023. Repeat imaging revealed significant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging.

answers.main_question: Was there missed, insufficient or incorrect documentation in the defendant’s medical history or physical exam?
answers.raw_answer: Yes. There was insufficient documentation in the defendant's medical history and physical exam, specifically a lack of documented nursing neurological assessments from 4:00 p.m. on February 24, 2023, through 8:00 a.m. on February 25, 2023, despite the patient's risk for neurological decline. [Source: Document 3]

History of Present Illness (Daniel Y. Suh MD; 6/5/2023 6:30 PM)
The patient is a 53 year old male who is being seen for telemedicine visit. Patient requested telemedicine consultation via the telephone. I've talked with his spouse. Patient is a 53-year-old man status post right-sided decompressive hemicraniectomy for management of a large right MCA distribution infarction. He is in rehabilitation. His wife is calling about reimplantation of his bone flap. She describes his craniotomy site is sunken in. We'll need to schedule this through the Memorial Hospital. I've suggested a CT scan to help with planning of his surgery. In all likelihood will be over place his own bone flap. There is a possibility if there is still brain fullness that we would have to use a contoured implant such as titanium mesh plate or even methylmethacrylate type plate. She's going to get the CT scan and sent us the results.

emorial, Mr. Ward was taken for an urgent thrombectomy of the right middle cerebral artery. As a result of the thrombectomy, Mr. Ward had reported improved blood flow.
22.
Following the thrombectomy, Mr. Ward was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit ("ICU") for continued monitoring and a higher level of care.
23.
One concern for patients who have suffered stroke is brain swelling that often occurs as a consequence of the stroke. If the brain swells too much, the swelling will cause further injury and possible hemorrhage to the brain.
24.
To control the swelling, Plaintiff's treating neurosurgeon, Dr. Daniel Suh, ordered a 3% saline solution which was delivered to Mr. Ward starting on February 19, 2023.
25.

Furthermore, on February 17, 2023, an order was entered by Kathleen Humkey, MD to perform neurological checks every hour.
26.
Between February 17 and February 23, 2023, Mr. Ward's physical, cognitive, and verbal condition improved.
27
On February 23, 2023 at 2:14a.m., a CT scan of Mr. Ward's showed "evolving large right MCA subacute infarct with stable mass effect and leftward midline shift of 5 mm, stable."
28.
At 11:06a.m., Dr. Osman Perez noted that Mr. Ward had a stable neurological exam and a stable CT scan. He further noted that Mr. Ward's best verbal response was "oriented", and his best motor response was "obeys commands." He also noted that an MRI was pending.
29.
At 11:23a.m., Dr. Suh noted that Mr. Ward's repeat CT scan was "stable with minimal shift no change." His plan was to continue with aggressive ICU care with 3% hypertonic saline and to slowly taper the hypertonic saline so his sodium could start to trend down.
30
On February 24, 2023, at 2:38a.m., a CT scan showed "Large subacute right MCA territory infarct is again noted with stable mass effect and leftward midline shift of 5 mm, previously 5 mm." The impression was again noted as stable.
31
At 10:49a.m. on February 24, 2023, Mr. Ward was discharged from the ICU to the internal medicine service on the medical floor of the Hospital (the "floor").
7

Before being discharged to the floor, Mr. Ward's saline therapy was discontinued.
33.

Eye Opening: Spontaneous Best Verbal Response: Oriented Best Motor Response: Obeys Commands Glasgow Coma Scale: 15
34.
At 5:49p.m. on February 24, 2023, Rachel Tinker, RN signed an order that was authorized by Thomas Allen, PA to perform neurological checks every four hours from February 24, 2023 at 8:00p.m. until otherwise specified.
35.
Periodic neurological checks were necessary since Mr. Ward remained at risk for brain swelling, subsequent stroke or other adverse neurological events. A decline in motor, verbal or cognitive ability would be a sign that Mr. Ward required immediate medical attention and warrant additional diagnostic imaging, such as a CT Scan, to rule out additional brain injury as a cause of the decline.
36.
At 7:28p.m. on February 24, 2023, Dr. Suh noted that Mr. Ward was stable overnight and was moved to the floor. He indicated that the repeat CT scan from that morning was "stable with minimal shift no change." His neurological exam noted the following: "sleeping but arouses. Left hemiplegia. States name and following commands briskly on the right."
8

sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.
14
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
> wiwo - Clerk of Court
62
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mr. Ward has incurred and continues to incur medical expenses, has lost and continues to lose wages, has suffered and continues to suffer severe pain, mental anguish, fear, shock and horror of his condition, loss of use of his body, loss of enjoyment of life, severe impairment of health and vigor physically and mentally, permanent disfigurement, loss of capacity to labor, physical confinement, and other harms and losses entitling Plaintiff Mr. Ward to compensation in an amount to be determined by the enlightened consciousness of a jury.
63.
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mrs. Ward has lost the society, companionship, and services of her husband.
Count I: Professional Negligence (All Defendants)
64.

answers.main_question: If Yes or Unclear, what elements were missing or insufficient?
answers.answer: The missing or insufficient elements in the documentation include: - **Cranial nerve and sensory assessments**: The neurological exam noted deficits (e.g., left facial droop, decreased sensation, hemiparesis) but stated that the remainder of the cranial nerves and sensory functions were "difficult to assess" without further clarification or follow-up. - **Cognitive assessment**: While lethargy was noted, no detailed cognitive evaluation or mental status examination was documented beyond "easily aroused." - **Insurance coverage discussion**: It was noted that expected insurance coverage and out-of-pocket expenses were "not applicable," but no further explanation was provided. - **Fall risk details**: Fall risk was assessed as "Yes," but no specific details or follow-up actions were documented. - **Pressure ulcer risk**: The patient was identified as at risk for pressure ulcers (score ≤18), but no specific interventions or reassessments were documented. These gaps could impact care planning and outcomes.
answers.raw_answer:
The missing or insufficient elements in the documentation include:  

- **Cranial nerve and sensory assessments**: The neurological exam noted deficits (e.g., left facial droop, decreased sensation, hemiparesis) but stated that the remainder of the cranial nerves and sensory functions were "difficult to assess" without further clarification or follow-up. [Source: Document 4]  
- **Cognitive assessment**: While lethargy was noted, no detailed cognitive evaluation or mental status examination was documented beyond "easily aroused." [Source: Document 4]  
- **Insurance coverage discussion**: It was noted that expected insurance coverage and out-of-pocket expenses were "not applicable," but no further explanation was provided. [Source: Document 1]  
- **Fall risk details**: Fall risk was assessed as "Yes," but no specific details or follow-up actions were documented. [Source: Document 2, Document 3]  
- **Pressure ulcer risk**: The patient was identified as at risk for pressure ulcers (score ≤18), but no specific interventions or reassessments were documented. [Source: Document 5]  

These gaps could impact care planning and outcomes.

answers.main_question: Was this a deviation from acceptable practice?
answers.raw_answer: Yes. The failure to perform timely neurological assessments, notify physicians of changes in condition, and act promptly on imaging orders constitutes a deviation from the standard of care expected in similar circumstances. [Sources: Document 1, Document 3, Document 4, Document 5]

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.

The medical records indicate instances of insufficient documentation, such as the lack of clarity regarding the severity of the patient's condition (e.g., cerebral edema or brain herniation) and the absence of detailed documentation for certain clinical decisions and complications (e.g., acute blood loss anemia and cardiac arrest). These omissions deviate from acceptable practice as they hinder accurate diagnosis, treatment planning, and continuity of care.

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.
14
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
> wiwo - Clerk of Court
62
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mr. Ward has incurred and continues to incur medical expenses, has lost and continues to lose wages, has suffered and continues to suffer severe pain, mental anguish, fear, shock and horror of his condition, loss of use of his body, loss of enjoyment of life, severe impairment of health and vigor physically and mentally, permanent disfigurement, loss of capacity to labor, physical confinement, and other harms and losses entitling Plaintiff Mr. Ward to compensation in an amount to be determined by the enlightened consciousness of a jury.
63.
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mrs. Ward has lost the society, companionship, and services of her husband.
Count I: Professional Negligence (All Defendants)
64.
Plaintiffs incorporate the paragraphs above as if fully restated herein.
65.

answers.main_question: Did it likely impact the patient’s care or outcome?
answers.raw_answer: Yes. Insufficient documentation regarding changes in mental status and treatment adjustments following significant imaging findings likely delayed appropriate interventions, which could have impacted the patient's outcome, including complications like brain herniation and cardiac arrest. [Sources: Document 4, Document 5]

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: T to STAT in the system RN informed wife and said transport would be there soon. RN checked on other patients. When the neurosurgeon asked for RN and asked why patient had not been down to CT yet, RN
sources.chunk_full:
T to STAT in the system RN informed wife and said transport would be there soon. RN checked on other patients. When the neurosurgeon asked for RN and asked why patient had not been down to CT yet, RN informed surgeon that she was coming to ask where transport was because RN could not leave the floor due to having 6 other patients with varying acuity. A call was made down to transport about the severity of this and the urgency needed for patient. Charge nurse stepped in and transported patient down to CT with HUC. Patient then went to PACU and did not return to the floor. RN called and gave report to PACU nurse.
56.
At 1:32p.m. February 27, 2023, Dr. Suh began performing an emergent decompressive hemicraniectomy surgery.
57.
Surgery ended at 4:08p.m. and Mr. Ward was brought to the ICU.
58.
At 7:03p.m., Dr. Osman Perez, critical care physician in the ICU, documented the following in his interval history for Mr. Ward:
. Repeat head CT on 02/24 showed a stable exam with similar 5 mm shift.
. On 02/26 around 01:00 the patient was taken for MRI BATT which had been ordered as part of his initial stroke workup but had not been done due to patient clinical status. MRI BATT showed evolving large right MCA territory subacute infarction with regions of hemosiderin deposition with 1.2 cm of leftward midline shift. This was significantly increased leftward shift when compared to CT scan from 02/24. This was noted in the primary team's note, however no documentation about a change in mental status or plan for adjustment of treatment based on those findings.
. On 02/27 patient was reportedly still more somnolent so a CT head was ordered which showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles. It also showed conclusion of right MCA territory infarction with no lobar hemorrhage.
. Based on this imaging, neurosurgery decided to take the patient for right hemicraniectomy with placement of an ICP monitor. The plan is for the patient to remain intubated following the procedure. He also received a PICC line for 3% NS
59.
Following the hemicraniectomy surgery, Mr. Ward remained at Savannah Memorial until May 3, 2023, during which time, he experienced numerous complications, many of which were due to Hospital neglect. For instance, there were two occasions where Mr. Ward bled profusely
13
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
VINOS
- Clerk of Court
and most nearly bled out before receiving any medical attention. On the second occasion, Mr. Ward coded twice due to blood loss. His discharge summary described the following hospital course, including the second profuse bleeding event on April 12, 2023 where Mr. Ward was found covered in blood and which led to him suffering cardiac arrest.
53-year-old male with past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus who presented initially to an outside hospital with acute onset of left-sided weakness on 2/17/2023. OSH imaging revealed right M1 occlusion and patient received TNK at OSH. He was transferred to our facility for LVO thrombectomy with Interventional Radiology which was completed shortly after admission to our facility on 2/17/2023. Repeat imaging revealed significant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging.

answers.main_question: Did the defendant fail to timely engage any indicated consultants to assess the patient?
answers.raw_answer: Yes. Neurosurgery was not consulted until February 19, 2023, despite significant edema and mass effect being noted earlier. Additionally, there were no documented nursing neurological assessments from 4:00 p.m. on February 24, 2023, to 8:00 a.m. on February 25, 2023, despite the patient being at risk for worsening neurological conditions. [Sources: Document 1, Document 3]

emorial, Mr. Ward was taken for an urgent thrombectomy of the right middle cerebral artery. As a result of the thrombectomy, Mr. Ward had reported improved blood flow.
22.
Following the thrombectomy,
sources.chunk_full:
emorial, Mr. Ward was taken for an urgent thrombectomy of the right middle cerebral artery. As a result of the thrombectomy, Mr. Ward had reported improved blood flow.
22.
Following the thrombectomy, Mr. Ward was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit ("ICU") for continued monitoring and a higher level of care.
23.
One concern for patients who have suffered stroke is brain swelling that often occurs as a consequence of the stroke. If the brain swells too much, the swelling will cause further injury and possible hemorrhage to the brain.
24.
To control the swelling, Plaintiff's treating neurosurgeon, Dr. Daniel Suh, ordered a 3% saline solution which was delivered to Mr. Ward starting on February 19, 2023.
25.
6
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
د ....
- Clerk of Court
Furthermore, on February 17, 2023, an order was entered by Kathleen Humkey, MD to perform neurological checks every hour.
26.
Between February 17 and February 23, 2023, Mr. Ward's physical, cognitive, and verbal condition improved.
27
On February 23, 2023 at 2:14a.m., a CT scan of Mr. Ward's showed "evolving large right MCA subacute infarct with stable mass effect and leftward midline shift of 5 mm, stable."
28.
At 11:06a.m., Dr. Osman Perez noted that Mr. Ward had a stable neurological exam and a stable CT scan. He further noted that Mr. Ward's best verbal response was "oriented", and his best motor response was "obeys commands." He also noted that an MRI was pending.
29.
At 11:23a.m., Dr. Suh noted that Mr. Ward's repeat CT scan was "stable with minimal shift no change." His plan was to continue with aggressive ICU care with 3% hypertonic saline and to slowly taper the hypertonic saline so his sodium could start to trend down.
30
On February 24, 2023, at 2:38a.m., a CT scan showed "Large subacute right MCA territory infarct is again noted with stable mass effect and leftward midline shift of 5 mm, previously 5 mm." The impression was again noted as stable.
31
At 10:49a.m. on February 24, 2023, Mr. Ward was discharged from the ICU to the internal medicine service on the medical floor of the Hospital (the "floor").
7
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
Jiwa - Clerk of Court
32.
Before being discharged to the floor, Mr. Ward's saline therapy was discontinued.
33.
From 6:00a.m. until 4:00pm. on February 24, 2023, the nursing flowsheets all indicate the following:
Eye Opening: Spontaneous Best Verbal Response: Oriented Best Motor Response: Obeys Commands Glasgow Coma Scale: 15
34.
At 5:49p.m. on February 24, 2023, Rachel Tinker, RN signed an order that was authorized by Thomas Allen, PA to perform neurological checks every four hours from February 24, 2023 at 8:00p.m. until otherwise specified.
35.
Periodic neurological checks were necessary since Mr. Ward remained at risk for brain swelling, subsequent stroke or other adverse neurological events. A decline in motor, verbal or cognitive ability would be a sign that Mr. Ward required immediate medical attention and warrant additional diagnostic imaging, such as a CT Scan, to rule out additional brain injury as a cause of the decline.
36.
At 7:28p.m. on February 24, 2023, Dr. Suh noted that Mr. Ward was stable overnight and was moved to the floor. He indicated that the repeat CT scan from that morning was "stable with minimal shift no change." His neurological exam noted the following: "sleeping but arouses. Left hemiplegia. States name and following commands briskly on the right."
8
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
Jiwa - Clerk of Court
37.
There were no documented nursing neurological assessments from 4:00p.m. on February 24, 2023 through 8:00a.m. on February 25, 2023.
38.
At 8:00a.m. on February 25, 2023, the nursing assessment was as follows:
Eye Opening: To Sound Best Verbal Response: Confused Best Motor Response: Obeys Commands Glasgow Coma Scale: 13
39.
Despite this decline in Mr. Ward's neurological exam from the day before, the nurses did not inform any physicians regarding Mr.

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.
14
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
> wiwo - Clerk of Court
62
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mr. Ward has incurred and continues to incur medical expenses, has lost and continues to lose wages, has suffered and continues to suffer severe pain, mental anguish, fear, shock and horror of his condition, loss of use of his body, loss of enjoyment of life, severe impairment of health and vigor physically and mentally, permanent disfigurement, loss of capacity to labor, physical confinement, and other harms and losses entitling Plaintiff Mr. Ward to compensation in an amount to be determined by the enlightened consciousness of a jury.
63.
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mrs. Ward has lost the society, companionship, and services of her husband.
Count I: Professional Negligence (All Defendants)
64.
Plaintiffs incorporate the paragraphs above as if fully restated herein.
65.

Ward, Frank MRN: 40162221, DOB: 11/12/1969, Legal Sex: M Adm: 2/17/2023, D/C: 5/3/2023
02/17/2023 - ED to Hosp-Admission (Discharged) in SAV 2 HV NEURO ICU (continued)
Clinical Notes-Abstract (continued)
Patient Identifiers: Frank Ward 53 y.o.male 11/12/1969 40162221
ED Bed Date/Time: 2/17/2023 8:58
Attending Provider: Nikola Tankosic, MD
Patient Care Team: No Primary Or Family Physician as PCP - General
Reason for Consult: Asystole arrest
HPI
53yoM - no established cardiologist in place - patient has had a complex hospital stay - hospital day 54 recently upgraded to ICU level of care - pmhx of DM II, BMI 35.44. Presented to an OSH on 02/17/23 with an acute onset of left-sided weakness. Found to be in hypotensive emergency, and given labetalol and started on a Cardene drip. Treated in ICU - Initial CT head w/o contrast showed no intracranial hemorrhage and patient received thrombolytics on 02/17/23 at the outside hospital. Transferred to MH for higher level of care. On arrival to our facility patient was found to have a persistent left-sided deficit with hemiplegia, visual and tactile neglect, and right gaze deviation. Interventional Radiology was called and the patient was taken for urgent thrombectomy. Patient underwent partially successful and uncomplicated aspiration and mechanical thrombectomy of the right middle cerebral artery with some reported improved flow.
While in the neuro ICU subsequent CT head without contrast showed a large MCA territory infarct with mild mass effect, no midline shift and no hemorrhagic transformation. Given concerns of possible worsening swelling given large CVA territory, patient was started on hypertonic saline which he reached appropriate goal for 48 hours and subsequent CT imaging had no evidence of worsening edema or hemorrhagic conversion. On 2/27, he was noted to have increasing somnolence and was taken for CT scan. This showed malignant cerebral edema and he was taken urgently for a decompressive R craniectomy. He was brought back to ICU post-operatively. He failed a trial of extubation and underwent tracheostomy 3/10/23. Pulmonary will follow for trach management.
His ICU course was complicated by pseudomonal and staphylococcal infections (both methicillin sensitive and resistant isolates). He has been on antibiotics and is currently on them for pneumonia. He has recently been febrile. He developed acute renal failure and was initiated on dialysis 3/27. Nephrology is following. On 4/11/2023 the patient had bleeding initially thought to be around the trach site. Ultimately was found that it was coming from the site of his IVC filter placement and a suture was placed and was transfused for a hgb of 5.6. Bleeding has now stabilized. He was briefly in step-down but was transition back to the ICU Patient was re-initiated on sedation and mechanical ventilation as he became lethargic during all this. Per ICU notes patient became bradycardic but rebounded without intervention. At approximately 8am this morning the patient had a long asystole arrest. Responded to atropine. He again had an asystole arrest at 10am requiring brief CPR. He was again given atropine. His sedation has been weaned as able. He is currently normal sinus rhythm on telemetry. He has had episodes of junctional bradycardia as well as brief Mobitz type 2 today. Cardiology has been asked to consult because of this.
Problem List
.

answers.main_question: Which consultations should have been requested or requested sooner?
answers.answer: A: Neurology and neurosurgery consultations should have been requested or requested sooner to address the patient's evolving neurological symptoms, including somnolence, mental status changes, and evidence of cerebral edema and infarction.
answers.raw_answer: A: Neurology and neurosurgery consultations should have been requested or requested sooner to address the patient's evolving neurological symptoms, including somnolence, mental status changes, and evidence of cerebral edema and infarction. [Sources: Document 1, Document 2, Document 4, Document 5]

He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.
14

answers.main_question: Was this a deviation from acceptable practice?
answers.raw_answer: Yes. The failure to timely engage indicated consultants, such as neurosurgery after the patient's condition deteriorated, constitutes a deviation from the standard of care expected in similar circumstances. [Source: Document 1, Document 3, Document 5]

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.
14

The delay in consulting neurosurgery and obtaining timely imaging contributed to the progression of the patient's brain herniation, necessitating a hemicraniectomy and leading to severe complications, including respiratory failure, renal failure, and long-term disability. [Sources: Document 1, Document 3, Document 5]

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.

Defendant NP Lokey held herself out to the public as a nurse practitioner competent to provide care and treatment within the standard of care and owed a duty to exercise that degree of care and skill ordinarily exercised by health care providers, generally, under like conditions and similar surrounding circumstances as those presented by Mr. Ward.
76.
NP Lokey was negligent and deviated from the standard of care ordinarily exercised by nurse practitioners under like conditions and similar surrounding circumstances by failing to follow up on the results of the MRI BATT when she was aware the study was pending on February 25, failing to initiate any interventions or notify a physician after Mr. Ward had gone from alert and oriented on February 24 to confused on February 25, and failing to perform any neurological assessments on February 26.
77.
The Neurological Institute is vicariously liable to Plaintiffs under the doctrine of respondeat superior and/or principles of agency law for all injuries and damages caused by their employees and/or agents including, but not limited to, NP Lokey and potentially other medical providers responsible for Mr. Ward's care.
78.
As a direct and proximate result of the Defendants' negligence, Mr. Ward suffered a brain herniation and had to undergo a hemicraniectomy.
18

VINOS - Clerk of Court
79.
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mr. Ward has incurred and continues to incur medical expenses, has lost and continues to lose wages, has suffered and continues to suffer pain, mental anguish, fear, shock and horror of his condition, loss of use of his body, loss of enjoyment of life, severe impairment of health and vigor physically and mentally, permanent disfigurement, loss of capacity to labor, physical confinement, and other harms and losses entitling Plaintiff Mr. Ward to compensation in an amount to be determined by the enlightened consciousness of a jury.
80.
As a result of her husband's stroke, Plaintiff Mrs. Ward has lost the society, companionship and services of her husband such that she too is entitled to compensation for loss of consortium in an amount to be determined by the enlightened consciousness of a jury.
81.
Defendants, in failing to get Plaintiff Mr.

answers.raw_answer: No. The defendant provided language assistance services and instructions for improving communication, including offering a medical interpreter and referring to Speech Pathology if needed. [Sources: Document 1, Document 2, Document 4]

answers.main_question: What communication barriers were not adequately addressed (e.g., health literacy, use of interpretation services)?
Was this a deviation from acceptable practice?
If Yes or Unclear, explain
Did it likely impact the patient’s care or outcome?
Explain
Was there missed, insufficient or incorrect documentation in this defendant’s initial clinical impression(s) and plan?
answers.raw_answer: Yes. The initial clinical impression and plan lacked sufficient documentation regarding the severity and specifics of the patient's condition, such as the absence of detailed information on cerebral edema, vasogenic edema, or brain herniation, as highlighted in the coding query. Additionally, there was no record of prior imaging or visit details from the outside facility, which could have provided critical context for the patient's condition. [Sources: Document 1, Document 2, Document 3, Document 4]

Electronically signed by: Peter Britt,
IR/ANGIOGRAPHY PROCEDURE Narrative Please see operative note which includes the physician's final narrative.
Most Recent Vitals: BP: 152/88 (02/17/23 1830) Heart Rate: 84 (02/17/23 1830) Resp: 24 (02/17/23 1830) Temp: 37.1 ℃ (98.8 ºF) (02/17/23 1600) SpO2: 96 % (02/17/23 1830) O2 Device: Room air (02/17/23 1136)
Medical Decision Making
Differential diagnosis ruled out based on history, presentation, exam: brain abscess, brain tumor, carbon monoxide exposure, carbon monoxide poisoning, CNS infection, cocaine abuse, seizure
Differential diagnosis: altered mental status, dehydration, dementia, depression, drug toxicity, electrolyte abnormality, hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, hypernatremia, hypoxia, intracranial hemorrhage, intracranial injury, pneumonia, urinary tract infection, sepsis, MI, Stroke, TIA
Impression: I have considered all serious diagnoses. WIII proceed with evaluation, testing and treatment as planned. Patient with left sided weakness, slurred speech. NIH stroke scale of 16. Plan on labs, ECG, radiologic imaging. Disposition pending test results and ED course. Patient arrived with no records of the visit from the outside facility and no records of the imaging reports. Teleneurology is evaluating the patient at bedside.
Diagnostic evaluation: H and P, radiologic imaging, ECG, labs, cardiac monitor.
Amount of complexity of data: EM physician performed face to face evaluation. Reviewed current ECG, current labs, current radiologic test, medical records
0857: I did discuss with Dr. O'Kelly on-call for Interventional Radiology who was aware of the patient. He is currently on the way to the hospital and will review the imaging to evaluate for the possibility of intervention.
