answers.main_question: Explain
answers.answer: The delayed diagnosis and treatment of Mr. Ward's condition, including the uncal and subfalcine herniation identified on 2/27/2023, led to significant complications such as brainstem compression, respiratory failure, tracheostomy, acute blood loss anemia, cardiac arrest, and temporary renal failure. These complications resulted in prolonged hospitalization, the need for rehabilitation, permanent disfigurement, and ongoing medical care.
answers.raw_answer: The delayed diagnosis and treatment of Mr. Ward's condition, including the uncal and subfalcine herniation identified on 2/27/2023, led to significant complications such as brainstem compression, respiratory failure, tracheostomy, acute blood loss anemia, cardiac arrest, and temporary renal failure. These complications resulted in prolonged hospitalization, the need for rehabilitation, permanent disfigurement, and ongoing medical care. [Sources: Document 4, Document 5]

A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.

sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.

answers.main_question: If you identified any deviation(s) from acceptable practice in Q1-9, are there reasonable explanations or justifications for the defendant’s actions?
answers.raw_answer: No. The deviations from acceptable practice, including delayed communication, inadequate documentation, and failure to act promptly on critical findings, lack reasonable justifications. The records show multiple missed opportunities to address the patient's worsening condition and lapses in coordination among providers, which directly impacted the patient's care and outcome. [Sources: Document 1, Document 2, Document 3, Document 5]

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: T to STAT in the system RN informed wife and said transport would be there soon. RN checked on other patients. When the neurosurgeon asked for RN and asked why patient had not been down to CT yet, RN
sources.chunk_full:
T to STAT in the system RN informed wife and said transport would be there soon. RN checked on other patients. When the neurosurgeon asked for RN and asked why patient had not been down to CT yet, RN informed surgeon that she was coming to ask where transport was because RN could not leave the floor due to having 6 other patients with varying acuity. A call was made down to transport about the severity of this and the urgency needed for patient. Charge nurse stepped in and transported patient down to CT with HUC. Patient then went to PACU and did not return to the floor. RN called and gave report to PACU nurse.
56.
At 1:32p.m. February 27, 2023, Dr. Suh began performing an emergent decompressive hemicraniectomy surgery.
57.
Surgery ended at 4:08p.m. and Mr. Ward was brought to the ICU.
58.
At 7:03p.m., Dr. Osman Perez, critical care physician in the ICU, documented the following in his interval history for Mr. Ward:
. Repeat head CT on 02/24 showed a stable exam with similar 5 mm shift.
. On 02/26 around 01:00 the patient was taken for MRI BATT which had been ordered as part of his initial stroke workup but had not been done due to patient clinical status. MRI BATT showed evolving large right MCA territory subacute infarction with regions of hemosiderin deposition with 1.2 cm of leftward midline shift. This was significantly increased leftward shift when compared to CT scan from 02/24. This was noted in the primary team's note, however no documentation about a change in mental status or plan for adjustment of treatment based on those findings.
. On 02/27 patient was reportedly still more somnolent so a CT head was ordered which showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles. It also showed conclusion of right MCA territory infarction with no lobar hemorrhage.
. Based on this imaging, neurosurgery decided to take the patient for right hemicraniectomy with placement of an ICP monitor. The plan is for the patient to remain intubated following the procedure. He also received a PICC line for 3% NS
59.
Following the hemicraniectomy surgery, Mr. Ward remained at Savannah Memorial until May 3, 2023, during which time, he experienced numerous complications, many of which were due to Hospital neglect. For instance, there were two occasions where Mr. Ward bled profusely
13
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
VINOS
- Clerk of Court
and most nearly bled out before receiving any medical attention. On the second occasion, Mr. Ward coded twice due to blood loss. His discharge summary described the following hospital course, including the second profuse bleeding event on April 12, 2023 where Mr. Ward was found covered in blood and which led to him suffering cardiac arrest.
53-year-old male with past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus who presented initially to an outside hospital with acute onset of left-sided weakness on 2/17/2023. OSH imaging revealed right M1 occlusion and patient received TNK at OSH. He was transferred to our facility for LVO thrombectomy with Interventional Radiology which was completed shortly after admission to our facility on 2/17/2023. Repeat imaging revealed significant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging.

answers.main_question: Explain
Please provide any additional insights related to the diagnostic workup process that may impact our understanding of the medical care provided.
answers.answer: The diagnostic workup process revealed significant lapses in communication, documentation, and timely action on critical findings. Specifically, delays in acting on the 2/26/2023 MRI findings and subsequent CT imaging on 2/27/2023 contributed to a delayed diagnosis of brain herniation and associated complications. Additionally, inadequate documentation of testing rationale and interpretation of results likely hindered coordination among providers, further impacting the patient's care and outcomes.

[Sources: Documents 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

On 02/27 patient was reportedly still more somnolent so a CT head was ordered which showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles. It also showed conclusion of right MCA territory infarction with no lobar hemorrhage.
. Based on this imaging, neurosurgery decided to take the patient for right hemicraniectomy with placement of an ICP monitor. The plan is for the patient to remain intubated following the procedure. He also received a PICC line for 3% NS
59.
Following the hemicraniectomy surgery, Mr. Ward remained at Savannah Memorial until May 3, 2023, during which time, he experienced numerous complications, many of which were due to Hospital neglect. For instance, there were two occasions where Mr. Ward bled profusely
13

VINOS
- Clerk of Court
and most nearly bled out before receiving any medical attention. On the second occasion, Mr. Ward coded twice due to blood loss. His discharge summary described the following hospital course, including the second profuse bleeding event on April 12, 2023 where Mr. Ward was found covered in blood and which led to him suffering cardiac arrest.
53-year-old male with past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus who presented initially to an outside hospital with acute onset of left-sided weakness on 2/17/2023. OSH imaging revealed right M1 occlusion and patient received TNK at OSH. He was transferred to our facility for LVO thrombectomy with Interventional Radiology which was completed shortly after admission to our facility on 2/17/2023. Repeat imaging revealed significant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging.

answers.main_question: Did the defendant fail to engage any indicated consultants or utilize external resources to arrive at a treatment plan?

When these samples are used in this manner, your privacy is safeguarded consistent with applicable federal and state privacy laws.
5. Consent to Medication Not Yet FDA Approved and/or Medication Prepared/Repackaged by Outsourcing or Compounding Pharmacy. As part of the services provided, you may be treated with a medication that has not received FDA approval. You may also receive a medication that has been prepared or repackaged by an outsourcing facility or compounding pharmacy. Certain medications for which there are no alternatives or which your physician recommends may be necessary for potentially life-saving treatment.
6. Consent to Product Patient Assistance Programs Limited Power of Attorney ("LPOA"). The Provider may be able to get free replacement or reimbursement for the cost of your drugs or medical products from the companies that make them through a patient assistance program sponsored by the companies that make your drugs or medical products and through charity foundations. If the hospital obtains replacement or reimbursement of cost of your drug or medical product from the manufacturer through such programs, the charge for the product or drug will be removed from your bill. Patient assistance programs require you to sign an application form in order for the hospital to obtain replacement or credits of certain drugs administered or devices implanted to qualifying patients. This LPOA allows the Provider and its claims processor to complete and sign your patient assistance program applications for you for so long as this program may be available to you.
I hereby appoint hospital and/or its claims processor, my attorney-in-fact for the sole and exclusive purpose of signing patient assistance program application forms on my behalf, so that hospital may attempt to obtain replacement or credits of certain drugs administered or devices implanted from the companies that make them. I understand that the final decision as to my acceptance in a patient assistance program lies with each pharmaceutical or medical device company and that submission by hospital provides no guarantee or assurance that any application will be approved. I will provide reasonable assistance and additional information and documentation as necessary to support each application. I further understand that: 1) signing this is voluntary;

Sometimes, after your visit there might be excess or leftover biological samples no longer needed for your care. These samples are usually discarded. However, sometimes these samples might be used for research within our hospitals and occasionally made available to researchers at external groups such as universities, private companies, advocacy groups, and government agencies. The research can help answer questions about the causes of diseases, how to prevent them, or even how to treat them. Please note that for this kind of research, (i) there might be no practical way to inform you about the details or results of the research (even if it involves genetic research), (ii) generally, no results on tests performed on your samples during the research can be returned to you or entered into your health record, (iii) it is not likely that you will directly benefit from the research, and (iv) there are no plans to compensate or recognize you for use of your samples or any discoveries made during the research. sources.chunk_preview: on which multiple providers noted, but failed to take appropriate action. After Mr. Ward started to decline, he had an MRI of his brain. The MRI showed a recent and evolving brain bleed which would ex
sources.chunk_full:
on which multiple providers noted, but failed to take appropriate action. After Mr. Ward started to decline, he had an MRI of his brain. The MRI showed a recent and evolving brain bleed which would explain Mr. Ward's decline and required immediate attention. Still, the Hospital did nothing. More than 30 hours after Mr. Ward's MRI exam, he had a CT Scan of his head, confirming a brain bleed and compression of his brainstem as a result of brain swelling. As a result of Defendants' delays, Mr. Ward suffered severe brain damage. Mr. Ward now requires around-the-clock care as a result of Defendants' lack of proper care.
Parties, Jurisdiction and Venue
2.
Plaintiffs Frank Ward and Rachael Ward reside in Sparks, Nevada. Plaintiffs subject themselves to the jurisdiction and venue of this Court.
3.
Defendant Savannah Health Services, LLC d/b/a Memorial Health University Medical Center ("Memorial Health") owns and operates a hospital ("Hospital") located at 4700 Waters Ave., Savannah, Chatham County, Georgia 31404. Memorial Health is part of a provider network and subsidiary of HCA Healthcare and as such has its principal place of business located at One Park Plaza, Nashville, Tennessee 37203. Defendant Memorial Health may be served with process upon its registered agent The Corporation Company at 410 Peachtree Parkway Suite 4245, Cumming, Forsyth County, Georgia 30041.
2

5.
At all times material hereto, Defendant Nurse Roy was an employee, agent and/or ostensible agent of Defendant Memorial Health and was acting within the course and scope of her employment and/or agency with Memorial Health. As such, Memorial Health is liable to Plaintiffs under respondeat superior and/or agency theories for her negligent actions.

l obligations "I" or "me" may also, depending on the context, mean financial guarantor "Guarantor".

sources.chunk_full:
l obligations "I" or "me" may also, depending on the context, mean financial guarantor "Guarantor".
"Provider" means the hospital and may include healthcare professionals on the hospital's staff and/or hospital- based physicians, which include but are not limited to: Emergency Department Physicians, Pathologists, Radiologists, Anesthesiologists, Hospitalists, certain other licensed independent practitioners and any authorized agents, contractors, affiliates, successors or assignees acting on their behalf.
1. Legal Relationship between Hospital and Physicians and Advanced Practice Professionals. I understand and acknowledge that the physicians and advanced practice professionals providing services to me in the hospital are independent contractors and not agents or employees of the hospital. "Advanced Practice Professionals" include, but are not limited to, my treating physicians/ surgeons, radiologists, pathologists, cardiologists, emergency physicians, anesthesiologists, contract physicians, hospital-based physicians, physician assistants, registered nurses, advanced practice registered nurses, certified nurse midwives, certified registered nurse anesthetists, clinical psychologists, clinical nurse specialists, doctors of nursing practice, radiology assistants, and anesthesiology assistants. Independent physicians and Advanced Practice Professionals are responsible for their own actions and the hospital shall not be liable for the acts or omissions of any such independent physicians and/or Advanced Practice Professionals.
2. Consent to Treatment. I consent to the procedures that may be performed during this hospitalization or during an outpatient episode of care, including, but not limited to, emergency treatment or services, and which may include laboratory procedures, x-ray examination, diagnostic procedures, medical, nursing or surgical treatment or procedures, anesthesia, or hospital services rendered as ordered by the Provider. I consent to allowing residents and other individuals enrolled in a healthcare professional education program as part of their training in health care education to participate in the delivery of my medical care and treatment or be observers while I receive medical care and treatment at the Hospital, and that they will be supervised by instructors and/or hospital staff. I further consent to the hospital conducting blood-borne infectious disease testing, including but not limited to, testing for hepatitis, Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome ("AIDS"), and Human Immunodeficiency Virus ("HIV"), if a Provider orders such tests or if ordered by protocol. I understand that the potential side effects and complications of this testing are generally minor and are comparable to the routine collection of blood specimens, including discomfort from the needle stick and/or slight burning, bleeding or soreness at the puncture site. The results of this test will become part of my confidential medical record.
3. Consent to Treatment Using Telemedicine. I consent to treatment involving the use of electronic communications ("Telemedicine") to enable health care providers at different locations to share my individual patient medical information for diagnosis, therapy, follow-up, and/or education purposes. I consent to forwarding my information to a third party as needed to receive Telemedicine services, and I understand that existing confidentiality protections apply. I acknowledge that while Telemedicine can be used to provide improved access

sources.chunk_full:
ient has a TRACH, begin TRACH collar trials for 15 minutes to 2 hours, TID; extend as tolerated.
- If the patient has an endotracheal tube:
a) Continue the trial for 30 minutes to 2 hours.
b) If patient successfully completes SBT, perform an assessment of the following parameters:
1. Rapid Shallow Breathing Index (f / Vt). 2. SpO2.
c) Notify the physician of the parameters listed in 8b. ABG is not required unless requested by physician. d) Obtain extubation orders from the physician (Physicians do not need to be contacted for TRACH patient).
9. X The SBT will be terminated when any of the following occur: a) HR greater than 140 or 20 % over baseline.
b) RR greater than 35 / min.
c) Systolic BP greater than 180 MM Hg.
d) Diastolic BP greater than 90 MM Hg.
e) SpO2 less than or equal to 90%.
f) Patient exhibits signs of anxiety or diaphoresis.
g) Rapid Shallow Breathing index (f / Vt) 50 - 100.
10. X If the patient has failed the SBT, return him / her to the prior ventilator settings. Consider adjusting pressure support settings for a RR of 12 - 24 if tolerated. Discuss interim settings with physician.

CONSENT TO TREAT: I understand that the hospital provides nursing, allied health, laboratory, radiology, diagnostic procedures, anesthesia, surgery suites and other facilities needed for my care and treatment and grant the hospital my consent for these services upon request and order of my physician(s). I further understand that my physician(s) are not controlled by the hospital and that the hospital cannot be responsible for the treatment decisions of my physician(s). I also understand that it is the responsibility of my physician(s) to fully explain the courses of treatment and procedures which he/she may deem advisable during my admission. I have the right to consent to, or refuse to consent to, any care and treatment decisions which may be made by my treating physician(s). Any questions regarding my course of treatment should be addressed to my physician(s).I agree and consent to the withdrawal and testing of my blood, without further consent by me, in the event that there is an accidental blood borne pathogen exposure during the procedure to any medical, nursing or other clinical staff, in order to test such blood for the presence of Hepatitis B virus or HBV, Hepatitis C virus or HCV, and Human Immunodeficiency Virus or HIV. I understand and agree that the results of such laboratory testing shall be maintained confidential, except to my treating healthcare providers, any clinical staff so exposed, and as may be allowed by any applicable state or federal statute, regulation or rule of law. There are other circumstances in which information must be disclosed to certain agencies. This may include reporting causes of HIV, tuberculosis and other diseases to authorized agencies such as the CDC, FDA, or state health departments. This reporting is required by state and/or federal requirements. This means that if any hospital personnel or physicians are exposed to my blood through a needle stick, blood splash or other means while I am being treated, I agree to allow my blood to be drawn and tested for HIV or Hepatitis. The results will be kept confidential except to my physician, any healthcare personnel caring for me, the hospital personnel exposed or as required or allowed by law. This will be at no charge to me.

4. Use of Biological Samples. During your care at the facility, biological samples (such as blood and tissue samples) might be collected from you for purposes of your care. Sometimes, after your visit there might be excess or leftover biological samples no longer needed for your care. These samples are usually discarded. However, sometimes these samples might be used for research within our hospitals and occasionally made available to researchers at external groups such as universities, private companies, advocacy groups, and government agencies. The research can help answer questions about the causes of diseases, how to prevent them, or even how to treat them. Please note that for this kind of research, (i) there might be no practical way to inform you about the details or results of the research (even if it involves genetic research), (ii) generally, no results on tests performed on your samples during the research can be returned to you or entered into your health record, (iii) it is not likely that you will directly benefit from the research, and (iv) there are no plans to compensate or recognize you for use of your samples or any discoveries made during the research. When these samples are used in this manner, your privacy is safeguarded consistent with applicable federal and state privacy laws.
5. Consent to Medication Not Yet FDA Approved and/or Medication Prepared/Repackaged by Outsourcing or Compounding Pharmacy. As part of the services provided, you may be treated with a medication that has not received FDA approval. You may also receive a medication that has been prepared or repackaged by an outsourcing facility or compounding pharmacy. Certain medications for which there are no alternatives or which your physician recommends may be necessary for potentially life-saving treatment.

Was this a deviation from acceptable practice?
If Yes or Unclear, explain
Did it likely impact the patient’s care or outcome?
If Yes or Unclear, explain
Was there delayed, insufficient or miscommunication between this defendant and the patient regarding the treatment plan?
answers.raw_answer: No. The records indicate consistent communication with the patient regarding the treatment plan, including explanations, demonstrations, and reinforcement of understanding. Communication impairments were addressed and resolved on 04/05/2023. [Sources: Document 1, Document 2, Document 4]

answers.main_question: If Yes or Unclear, specify what elements were missing or incorrect:
Was this a deviation from acceptable practice?
If Yes or Unclear, explain
Did it likely impact the patient’s care or outcome?
If Yes or Unclear, explain
Was there a missed, delayed, incorrect, or unindicated TREATMENT by this defendant?
answers.raw_answer: Yes. There was a delayed treatment as the patient experienced a significant delay in being transported for a CT scan on 2/27/2023, despite worsening symptoms, which contributed to the progression of his condition, including brain herniation and subsequent complications. [Source: Document 4]

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.

sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: T to STAT in the system RN informed wife and said transport would be there soon. RN checked on other patients. When the neurosurgeon asked for RN and asked why patient had not been down to CT yet, RN
sources.chunk_full:
T to STAT in the system RN informed wife and said transport would be there soon. RN checked on other patients. When the neurosurgeon asked for RN and asked why patient had not been down to CT yet, RN informed surgeon that she was coming to ask where transport was because RN could not leave the floor due to having 6 other patients with varying acuity. A call was made down to transport about the severity of this and the urgency needed for patient. Charge nurse stepped in and transported patient down to CT with HUC. Patient then went to PACU and did not return to the floor. RN called and gave report to PACU nurse.
56.
At 1:32p.m. February 27, 2023, Dr. Suh began performing an emergent decompressive hemicraniectomy surgery.
57.
Surgery ended at 4:08p.m. and Mr. Ward was brought to the ICU.
58.
At 7:03p.m., Dr. Osman Perez, critical care physician in the ICU, documented the following in his interval history for Mr. Ward:
. Repeat head CT on 02/24 showed a stable exam with similar 5 mm shift.
. On 02/26 around 01:00 the patient was taken for MRI BATT which had been ordered as part of his initial stroke workup but had not been done due to patient clinical status. MRI BATT showed evolving large right MCA territory subacute infarction with regions of hemosiderin deposition with 1.2 cm of leftward midline shift. This was significantly increased leftward shift when compared to CT scan from 02/24. This was noted in the primary team's note, however no documentation about a change in mental status or plan for adjustment of treatment based on those findings.
. On 02/27 patient was reportedly still more somnolent so a CT head was ordered which showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles. It also showed conclusion of right MCA territory infarction with no lobar hemorrhage.
. Based on this imaging, neurosurgery decided to take the patient for right hemicraniectomy with placement of an ICP monitor. The plan is for the patient to remain intubated following the procedure. He also received a PICC line for 3% NS
59.
Following the hemicraniectomy surgery, Mr. Ward remained at Savannah Memorial until May 3, 2023, during which time, he experienced numerous complications, many of which were due to Hospital neglect. For instance, there were two occasions where Mr. Ward bled profusely
13
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
VINOS
- Clerk of Court
and most nearly bled out before receiving any medical attention. On the second occasion, Mr. Ward coded twice due to blood loss. His discharge summary described the following hospital course, including the second profuse bleeding event on April 12, 2023 where Mr. Ward was found covered in blood and which led to him suffering cardiac arrest.
53-year-old male with past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus who presented initially to an outside hospital with acute onset of left-sided weakness on 2/17/2023. OSH imaging revealed right M1 occlusion and patient received TNK at OSH. He was transferred to our facility for LVO thrombectomy with Interventional Radiology which was completed shortly after admission to our facility on 2/17/2023. Repeat imaging revealed significant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging.

Defendant Dr. Thombs held himself out to the public as a physician competent to provide care and treatment within the standard of care and owed a duty to exercise that degree of care and skill ordinarily exercised by health care providers, generally, under like conditions and similar surrounding circumstances as those presented by Mr. Ward.
73.
Dr. Thombs was negligent and deviated from the standard of care ordinarily exercised by physicians under like conditions and similar surrounding circumstances by failing to order a CT scan and/or contact the neurosurgical team after Mr. Ward's MRI showed an evolving large right MCA territory subacute infarction with regions of hemosiderin deposition/petechial staining with 1.2 cm of leftward midline shift and failing to perform a neurological assessment on February 25 or February 26.

answers.main_question: Please describe the treatment issue - what was done in error and what should have been done instead:
answers.answer: The treatment issue involved a delay in addressing significant brain edema and herniation. Neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023, but the patient developed worsening symptoms, including somnolence, by 2/27/2023, when imaging showed severe brain herniation and compression. A decompressive craniectomy was performed on 2/27/2023, but earlier intervention might have prevented further complications, including brain injury.
answers.raw_answer: The treatment issue involved a delay in addressing significant brain edema and herniation. Neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023, but the patient developed worsening symptoms, including somnolence, by 2/27/2023, when imaging showed severe brain herniation and compression. A decompressive craniectomy was performed on 2/27/2023, but earlier intervention might have prevented further complications, including brain injury. [Source: Document 1, Document 2]

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.
14

answers.main_question: Did the treatment error occur secondary to and ONLY because of a diagnostic error?
answers.raw_answer: No. The treatment error occurred due to delayed action and failure to follow up on diagnostic findings, including not performing timely neurological assessments or acting on MRI results, rather than solely due to a diagnostic error. [Sources: Document 3, Document 4]

This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.

answers.main_question: If Yes or Unclear, explain:
answers.answer: Yes. The treatment error occurred due to a delay in initiating appropriate interventions for Mr. Ward's condition, including delayed decompressive craniectomy despite significant brain herniation and delayed management of respiratory failure requiring re-intubation and tracheostomy. These delays contributed to complications such as acute kidney injury, respiratory failure, and acute blood loss anemia.
answers.raw_answer: Yes. The treatment error occurred due to a delay in initiating appropriate interventions for Mr. Ward's condition, including delayed decompressive craniectomy despite significant brain herniation and delayed management of respiratory failure requiring re-intubation and tracheostomy. These delays contributed to complications such as acute kidney injury, respiratory failure, and acute blood loss anemia. [Sources: Document 1, Document 3, Document 5]

sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.
14
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
> wiwo - Clerk of Court
62
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mr. Ward has incurred and continues to incur medical expenses, has lost and continues to lose wages, has suffered and continues to suffer severe pain, mental anguish, fear, shock and horror of his condition, loss of use of his body, loss of enjoyment of life, severe impairment of health and vigor physically and mentally, permanent disfigurement, loss of capacity to labor, physical confinement, and other harms and losses entitling Plaintiff Mr. Ward to compensation in an amount to be determined by the enlightened consciousness of a jury.
63.
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mrs. Ward has lost the society, companionship, and services of her husband.
Count I: Professional Negligence (All Defendants)
64.
Plaintiffs incorporate the paragraphs above as if fully restated herein.
65.

answers.main_question: If this was a medication error, what type of error occurred?
answers.raw_answer: Other. The error appears to involve a lack of proper reinforcement and education on the medication regimen, as multiple instances of "Needs Reinforcement" were documented in patient education records. [Source: Document 1, Document 2]

answers.main_question: Was the treatment issue a deviation from acceptable practice?
answers.raw_answer: Yes. The documents indicate a delay in treatment for Mr. Ward's brain injury, which led to significant complications, including brain herniation, respiratory failure, and other severe health issues. This delay is alleged to constitute professional negligence. [Source: Document 1, Document 2]

sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.

answers.main_question: Did it likely impact the patient’s care or outcome?
answers.raw_answer: Yes. The delayed treatment, including failure to promptly order or act on imaging and neurological assessments, contributed to the progression of Mr. Ward's brain injury, leading to a herniation, hemicraniectomy, and subsequent complications. [Sources: Document 1, Document 3, Document 5]

sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.

sources.chunk_preview: T to STAT in the system RN informed wife and said transport would be there soon. RN checked on other patients. When the neurosurgeon asked for RN and asked why patient had not been down to CT yet, RN
sources.chunk_full:
T to STAT in the system RN informed wife and said transport would be there soon. RN checked on other patients. When the neurosurgeon asked for RN and asked why patient had not been down to CT yet, RN informed surgeon that she was coming to ask where transport was because RN could not leave the floor due to having 6 other patients with varying acuity. A call was made down to transport about the severity of this and the urgency needed for patient. Charge nurse stepped in and transported patient down to CT with HUC. Patient then went to PACU and did not return to the floor. RN called and gave report to PACU nurse.
56.
At 1:32p.m. February 27, 2023, Dr. Suh began performing an emergent decompressive hemicraniectomy surgery.
57.
Surgery ended at 4:08p.m. and Mr. Ward was brought to the ICU.
58.
At 7:03p.m., Dr. Osman Perez, critical care physician in the ICU, documented the following in his interval history for Mr. Ward:
. Repeat head CT on 02/24 showed a stable exam with similar 5 mm shift.
. On 02/26 around 01:00 the patient was taken for MRI BATT which had been ordered as part of his initial stroke workup but had not been done due to patient clinical status. MRI BATT showed evolving large right MCA territory subacute infarction with regions of hemosiderin deposition with 1.2 cm of leftward midline shift. This was significantly increased leftward shift when compared to CT scan from 02/24. This was noted in the primary team's note, however no documentation about a change in mental status or plan for adjustment of treatment based on those findings.
. On 02/27 patient was reportedly still more somnolent so a CT head was ordered which showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles. It also showed conclusion of right MCA territory infarction with no lobar hemorrhage.
. Based on this imaging, neurosurgery decided to take the patient for right hemicraniectomy with placement of an ICP monitor. The plan is for the patient to remain intubated following the procedure. He also received a PICC line for 3% NS
59.
Following the hemicraniectomy surgery, Mr. Ward remained at Savannah Memorial until May 3, 2023, during which time, he experienced numerous complications, many of which were due to Hospital neglect. For instance, there were two occasions where Mr. Ward bled profusely
13
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
VINOS
- Clerk of Court
and most nearly bled out before receiving any medical attention. On the second occasion, Mr. Ward coded twice due to blood loss. His discharge summary described the following hospital course, including the second profuse bleeding event on April 12, 2023 where Mr. Ward was found covered in blood and which led to him suffering cardiac arrest.
53-year-old male with past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus who presented initially to an outside hospital with acute onset of left-sided weakness on 2/17/2023. OSH imaging revealed right M1 occlusion and patient received TNK at OSH. He was transferred to our facility for LVO thrombectomy with Interventional Radiology which was completed shortly after admission to our facility on 2/17/2023. Repeat imaging revealed significant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging.

answers.main_question: If Yes or Unclear, explain:
answers.answer: Yes. The delay in treatment led to significant complications, including a brain injury with uncal herniation and brainstem compression requiring decompressive craniectomy, respiratory failure necessitating tracheostomy, acute blood loss anemia from a puncture site, and renal failure requiring hemodialysis. These complications resulted in prolonged hospitalization, long-term care needs, and permanent impairments.
answers.raw_answer: Yes. The delay in treatment led to significant complications, including a brain injury with uncal herniation and brainstem compression requiring decompressive craniectomy, respiratory failure necessitating tracheostomy, acute blood loss anemia from a puncture site, and renal failure requiring hemodialysis. These complications resulted in prolonged hospitalization, long-term care needs, and permanent impairments. [Source: Document 4, Document 5]

sources.file: Complaint.pdf
sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.

63.

answers.main_question: If you identified any deviation(s) from acceptable practice in Q1-9, are there reasonable explanations or justifications for the defendant’s actions?
answers.raw_answer: No. There are no reasonable explanations or justifications for the defendant's actions. The delay in addressing significant brain edema and herniation, despite worsening symptoms and imaging findings, represents a deviation from standard care without sufficient justification. Earlier intervention could have prevented severe complications. [Sources: Document 1, Document 3, Document 4, Document 5]

sources.chunk_full:
T to STAT in the system RN informed wife and said transport would be there soon. RN checked on other patients. When the neurosurgeon asked for RN and asked why patient had not been down to CT yet, RN informed surgeon that she was coming to ask where transport was because RN could not leave the floor due to having 6 other patients with varying acuity. A call was made down to transport about the severity of this and the urgency needed for patient. Charge nurse stepped in and transported patient down to CT with HUC. Patient then went to PACU and did not return to the floor. RN called and gave report to PACU nurse.
56.
At 1:32p.m. February 27, 2023, Dr. Suh began performing an emergent decompressive hemicraniectomy surgery.
57.
Surgery ended at 4:08p.m. and Mr. Ward was brought to the ICU.
58.
At 7:03p.m., Dr. Osman Perez, critical care physician in the ICU, documented the following in his interval history for Mr. Ward:
. Repeat head CT on 02/24 showed a stable exam with similar 5 mm shift.
. On 02/26 around 01:00 the patient was taken for MRI BATT which had been ordered as part of his initial stroke workup but had not been done due to patient clinical status. MRI BATT showed evolving large right MCA territory subacute infarction with regions of hemosiderin deposition with 1.2 cm of leftward midline shift. This was significantly increased leftward shift when compared to CT scan from 02/24. This was noted in the primary team's note, however no documentation about a change in mental status or plan for adjustment of treatment based on those findings.
. On 02/27 patient was reportedly still more somnolent so a CT head was ordered which showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles. It also showed conclusion of right MCA territory infarction with no lobar hemorrhage.
. Based on this imaging, neurosurgery decided to take the patient for right hemicraniectomy with placement of an ICP monitor. The plan is for the patient to remain intubated following the procedure. He also received a PICC line for 3% NS
59.
Following the hemicraniectomy surgery, Mr. Ward remained at Savannah Memorial until May 3, 2023, during which time, he experienced numerous complications, many of which were due to Hospital neglect. For instance, there were two occasions where Mr. Ward bled profusely

53-year-old male with past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus who presented initially to an outside hospital with acute onset of left-sided weakness on 2/17/2023. OSH imaging revealed right M1 occlusion and patient received TNK at OSH. He was transferred to our facility for LVO thrombectomy with Interventional Radiology which was completed shortly after admission to our facility on 2/17/2023. Repeat imaging revealed significant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging.

sources.chunk_full:
emorial, Mr. Ward was taken for an urgent thrombectomy of the right middle cerebral artery. As a result of the thrombectomy, Mr. Ward had reported improved blood flow.
22.
Following the thrombectomy, Mr. Ward was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit ("ICU") for continued monitoring and a higher level of care.
23.
One concern for patients who have suffered stroke is brain swelling that often occurs as a consequence of the stroke. If the brain swells too much, the swelling will cause further injury and possible hemorrhage to the brain.
24.
To control the swelling, Plaintiff's treating neurosurgeon, Dr. Daniel Suh, ordered a 3% saline solution which was delivered to Mr. Ward starting on February 19, 2023.
25.
6
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
د ....
- Clerk of Court
Furthermore, on February 17, 2023, an order was entered by Kathleen Humkey, MD to perform neurological checks every hour.
26.
Between February 17 and February 23, 2023, Mr. Ward's physical, cognitive, and verbal condition improved.
27
On February 23, 2023 at 2:14a.m., a CT scan of Mr. Ward's showed "evolving large right MCA subacute infarct with stable mass effect and leftward midline shift of 5 mm, stable."
28.
At 11:06a.m., Dr. Osman Perez noted that Mr. Ward had a stable neurological exam and a stable CT scan. He further noted that Mr. Ward's best verbal response was "oriented", and his best motor response was "obeys commands." He also noted that an MRI was pending.
29.
At 11:23a.m., Dr. Suh noted that Mr. Ward's repeat CT scan was "stable with minimal shift no change." His plan was to continue with aggressive ICU care with 3% hypertonic saline and to slowly taper the hypertonic saline so his sodium could start to trend down.
30
On February 24, 2023, at 2:38a.m., a CT scan showed "Large subacute right MCA territory infarct is again noted with stable mass effect and leftward midline shift of 5 mm, previously 5 mm." The impression was again noted as stable.
31
At 10:49a.m. on February 24, 2023, Mr. Ward was discharged from the ICU to the internal medicine service on the medical floor of the Hospital (the "floor").
7

32.
Before being discharged to the floor, Mr. Ward's saline therapy was discontinued.
33.
From 6:00a.m. until 4:00pm. on February 24, 2023, the nursing flowsheets all indicate the following:
Eye Opening: Spontaneous Best Verbal Response: Oriented Best Motor Response: Obeys Commands Glasgow Coma Scale: 15
34.
At 5:49p.m. on February 24, 2023, Rachel Tinker, RN signed an order that was authorized by Thomas Allen, PA to perform neurological checks every four hours from February 24, 2023 at 8:00p.m. until otherwise specified.
35.
Periodic neurological checks were necessary since Mr. Ward remained at risk for brain swelling, subsequent stroke or other adverse neurological events. A decline in motor, verbal or cognitive ability would be a sign that Mr. Ward required immediate medical attention and warrant additional diagnostic imaging, such as a CT Scan, to rule out additional brain injury as a cause of the decline.
36.
At 7:28p.m. on February 24, 2023, Dr. Suh noted that Mr. Ward was stable overnight and was moved to the floor. He indicated that the repeat CT scan from that morning was "stable with minimal shift no change." His neurological exam noted the following: "sleeping but arouses. Left hemiplegia. States name and following commands briskly on the right."

answers.main_question: If Yes or Unclear, explain:
Please provide any additional insights related to the patient treatment that may impact our understanding of the medical care provided.
answers.answer: The patient's treatment was marked by significant delays in addressing critical conditions, including brain herniation, respiratory failure, and acute blood loss anemia, which deviated from acceptable medical practice and contributed to severe complications, prolonged hospitalization, and long-term impairments. Earlier intervention, particularly timely decompressive craniectomy and proactive management of complications, could have potentially mitigated these outcomes.

. On 02/26 around 01:00 the patient was taken for MRI BATT which had been ordered as part of his initial stroke workup but had not been done due to patient clinical status. MRI BATT showed evolving large right MCA territory subacute infarction with regions of hemosiderin deposition with 1.2 cm of leftward midline shift. This was significantly increased leftward shift when compared to CT scan from 02/24. This was noted in the primary team's note, however no documentation about a change in mental status or plan for adjustment of treatment based on those findings.
. On 02/27 patient was reportedly still more somnolent so a CT head was ordered which showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles. It also showed conclusion of right MCA territory infarction with no lobar hemorrhage.
. Based on this imaging, neurosurgery decided to take the patient for right hemicraniectomy with placement of an ICP monitor. The plan is for the patient to remain intubated following the procedure. He also received a PICC line for 3% NS
59.
Following the hemicraniectomy surgery, Mr. Ward remained at Savannah Memorial until May 3, 2023, during which time, he experienced numerous complications, many of which were due to Hospital neglect. For instance, there were two occasions where Mr. Ward bled profusely
13
RECEIVED FOR FILING, STATE COURT CLERK CHATHAM CO. GA, 12/20/2024 3:24 PM
VINOS
- Clerk of Court
and most nearly bled out before receiving any medical attention. On the second occasion, Mr. Ward coded twice due to blood loss. His discharge summary described the following hospital course, including the second profuse bleeding event on April 12, 2023 where Mr. Ward was found covered in blood and which led to him suffering cardiac arrest.
53-year-old male with past medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus who presented initially to an outside hospital with acute onset of left-sided weakness on 2/17/2023. OSH imaging revealed right M1 occlusion and patient received TNK at OSH. He was transferred to our facility for LVO thrombectomy with Interventional Radiology which was completed shortly after admission to our facility on 2/17/2023. Repeat imaging revealed significant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging.

No verbal response this morning" and he was unable to perform a review of systems due to "mental status change." He noted that the brain MRI from 2/26/23 suggested increasing shift up to 1.2 cm. In his plan, he noted the following: "awaiting repeat CT head without contrast this morning. If shift is still increased past 1.0 cm, likely needs to transfer back to monitored unit and resume hypertonic saline. Will review CT once images available and base final recommendations of this newest scan."
51.
PA Allen' note at 9:36 a.m. on February 27, 2023 is the earliest documented record that the Hospital's neurological team was aware of Mr. Ward's "evolving" stroke. This time is 31 hours after the Hospital's radiologist read Mr. Ward's MRI report which showed an "evolving" stroke and 49.5 hours after Hospital nurses observed and noted Mr. Ward's cognitive decline.

sources.chunk_preview: gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm
sources.chunk_full:
gnificant edema and mass effect and neurosurgery was consulted on 2/19/2023. The patient remained alert during this time however on 2/27/2023 the patient became more somnolent and head CT showed 1 cm right uncal herniation with brainstem compression and 1.5 cm right to left subfalcine herniation with compression of bilateral ventricles with no evidence of hemorrhage and patient was taken that day for decompressive craniectomy with Neurosurgery. He remained intubated until 3/6/2023 but on 3/7/2023 the patient experienced respiratory failure with left lung mucus plugging resulting in full whiteout and requiring re-intubation. Ultimately, the patient received tracheostomy on 3/10/2023 for long vent wean as well as multiple bronchoscopies needing to be performed for significant mucus plugging. Patient also received IVC filter prophylactically secondary to inability to anticoagulate with large stroke burden around 3/3/2023 which was removed on 3/14/2023.
Around 3/24/2023 the patient's renal function declined without any inciting event. Ultimately he did require hemodialysis and received tunneled hemodialysis catheter on 3/27/2023. This catheter has since been removed and the patient's last hemodialysis was on 4/7/2023 and he now has full renal recovery.
Another complication during the patient's hospitalization was acute blood loss anemia secondary to significant bleeding from right IJ puncture site that was used for IVC filter retrieval. On 4/12/2023 the patient was found covered in blood which was noted to come from this site. A stitch was placed in the site and the bleeding did resolve however the patient became hemodynamically unstable secondary to acute blood loss. Hours after the bleeding had resolved and hemoglobin had remained stable after receiving MTP the patient did experience a short witnessed cardiac arrest with ROSC acheived quickly with one round of ACLS. There have not been any further episodes of bleeding since this event.
The remainder of the patient's hospitalization included vent weaning and ultimately tracheostomy decannulation on 5/2/2023. Patient is now tolerating oral diet by mouth but does still have PEG tube in place if needed. He is stable for discharge from acute hospitalization to rehab facility for further strengthening. Follow-up is needed with Dr. Suh (Neurosurgery) for timing craniectomy bone flap replacement.
This is a brief account of the patient's stay in the ICU. Please refer to EMR for complete record.
60.
Mr. Ward was discharged to Brooks Rehabilitation on May 3, 2023 where he remained through July 6, 2023.
61.
Following discharge from Brooks Rehabilitation, Mr. Ward required and continues to require around-the-clock care. Mrs. Ward had to quit her job and move herself and her husband to Sparks, Nevada, where she has family to help her care for her husband.
14

63.
As a result of Mr. Ward's brain injury due to Defendants' delay in treatment, Mrs. Ward has lost the society, companionship, and services of her husband.
Count I: Professional Negligence (All Defendants)

answers.main_question: Did the defendant perform or participate in a procedure or surgery (diagnostic OR therapeutic) on this patient?
answers.raw_answer: Yes. The defendant participated in multiple procedures on the patient, including an IR insertion of a central venous catheter for hemodialysis on 3/27/2023 and a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy on 3/21/2023. [Sources: Document 1, Document 4]

answers.main_question: What was the procedure(s) or surgery(ies)?
answers.answer: The procedures were: - Emergent Cerebral - LVO. - Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy. - IR Insertion of central venous catheter for hemodialysis. - Cranioplasty with autologous bone flap.
answers.raw_answer:
The procedures were:  
- Emergent Cerebral - LVO. [Source: Document 5]  
- Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy. [Source: Document 4]  
- IR Insertion of central venous catheter for hemodialysis. [Source: Document 1]  
- Cranioplasty with autologous bone flap. [Source: Documents 2, 3]

answers.main_question: Was the procedure or surgery involving this defendant unwarranted or performed WITHOUT an appropriate indication?
answers.raw_answer: No. The procedures performed, including the IR catheter insertion for hemodialysis and emergent cerebral intervention for LVO, were appropriately indicated based on the patient's medical conditions, such as the need for dialysis and acute cerebrovascular events. [Sources: Document 1, Document 3, Document 5]

XR KUB W CONTRAST TUBE PLACE
HISTORY: Confirm tube location new onset drainage and bruising noted by family
COMPARISON: X-ray abdomen March 20, 2023
FINDINGS: 2 AP images before and after administration of contrast via G-tube.
Bowel: Nonobstructive bowel gas pattern. Gastrostomy tube in place. The postcontrast image demonstrates oral contrast filling the gastric lumen with no evidence for extravasation.
Free air: There is no extraluminal air.
Bones: No acute fracture or concerning osseous lesion.
Soft tissues: Normal.
Impression:
Gastrostomy tube appears well-positioned with no evidence for contrast extravasation from the stomach.
The attending radiologist has reviewed all images, agrees with the interpretation, and provided appropriate supervision for this exam.
